questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of progressive numbness and weakness in her left arm and left leg for 2 days. During this period, she has also had urinary urgency and incontinence. Three months ago, she had blurry vision, difficulty distinguishing colors, and headache for one week, all of which have since resolved. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg. Muscle strength in the extremities is 3/5 on the left and 5/5 on the right. Upon flexion of the neck, the patient experiences a shooting electric sensation that travels down the spine. MRI of the brain shows gadolinium-enhancing lesions in the right central sulcus, cervical spinal cord, and optic nerve. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dimethyl fumarate is an immunomodulator that is used in disease-modifying MS therapy, particularly for patients with relapsing-remitting MS. Although this patient will most likely need disease-modifying therapy in the future, she first requires treatment for the acute exacerbation of her symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Interferon beta is an immunomodulator and a first-line agent for disease-modifying MS therapy, which helps prevent (not treat) exacerbations. Although this patient will most likely need disease-modifying therapy in the future, she first requires treatment for the acute exacerbation of her symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

The first-line management for acute MS exacerbation is high-dose IV glucocorticoids. Typically, 500–1000 mg of methylprednisolone are given daily for 3–5 days. As with any patient receiving high-dose glucocorticoids, a proton pump inhibitor to prevent gastritis should be given concurrently and patients should be monitored for hyperglycemia. Patients who do not respond to high-dose glucocorticoid therapy should be treated with plasmapheresis.
Image Description:

MRI cervical spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

At the level of the fourth cervical vertebral body, there is an area of poorly defined hyperintensity within the spinal cord (green overlay). The first cervical vertebra is not well visualized in this image due to its shape, whereas the second cervical vertebra is well recognized due to the superior projected bony element known as the dens or odontoid process.

This is an example of a demyelinating plaque in a patient with multiple sclerosis. Spinal cord demyelinating plaques from multiple sclerosis are most often found in the cervical segment of the cord. They are usually shorter than two vertebral bodies in length.

D) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis is the second-line treatment for acute MS exacerbations. If first-line treatment had failed or there were contraindications to it, then plasmapheresis would have been an appropriate treatment option.

E) INCORRECT:

Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is used for thrombolysis in patients with stroke. Although strokes often manifest with unilateral weakness and numbness, symptoms are typically acute rather than progressive. Additionally, this patient's MRI findings are not consistent with stroke.

F) INCORRECT:

Glatiramer acetate is a pharmacological option for disease-modifying MS therapy, which helps prevent (not treat) exacerbations. Although this patient will most likely need disease-modifying therapy in the future, she first requires treatment for the acute exacerbation of her symptoms.
questions.hint: This patient meets the revised McDonald criteria for multiple sclerosis (MS): two episodes of central neurological symptoms that occurred ≥ 30 days apart (prior visual changes suggesting optic neuritis and current unilateral numbness and motor weakness, Lhermitte sign, bladder dysfunction) and MRI showing lesions in different regions of the CNS that correlate with the symptoms. Her current presentation is consistent with an acute exacerbation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of increasing weakness and numbness of the upper extremities for 5 days. During this time, she has also had urinary incontinence unrelated to sneezing or laughing. She reports that last summer during a vacation in Mexico she had weakness and numbness of her right lower extremity that was worse when she was outside; she regained her strength 3 weeks later. She has no history of serious illness. She has had 10 male sexual partners in her lifetime and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an impaired tandem gait. There is mild spasticity and muscle strength is decreased in both upper extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Abdominal reflex is absent. Muscle strength in the right lower extremity is mildly decreased. Sensation to vibration and fine touch is decreased over the upper extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: MRI of the brain and spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause demyelination of the spinal cord, manifesting as subacute combined degeneration (SACD). SACD could explain many of this patient's symptoms, such as her sensory abnormalities, muscle spasticity and weakness, impaired tandem gait, and urinary incontinence. However, symptoms of SACD are generally symmetrical and involve the legs more than the arms. Furthermore, this patient does not have any other signs of vitamin B12 deficiency, such as fatigue, pallor, or glossitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibodies are used to screen for numerous rheumatic diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or Sjögren syndrome. Neurologic involvement is common in patients with SLE. However, the most common signs of SLE, including skin and joint involvement, are not present. Although SLE may manifest before the onset of other systemic findings, typical findings are cognitive dysfunction, strokes, seizures, and/or headaches, none of which are present in this patient.

Sjögren syndrome can manifest with a variety of focal and/or diffuse neurological abnormalities, e.g., impaired motor control, paresis, seizures, or peripheral neuropathy, making it an important differential diagnosis. But this patient's primary symptoms became worse in the summer heat and demonstrated complete remission, which is not expected with Sjögren syndrome. In addition, most patients with CNS SS also have signs of peripheral vasculitis affecting the skin and muscles such as ulcers or pain. However, in a clinical setting, if the next appropriate step is inconclusive, ANA testing may be considered.

C) INCORRECT:

Rapid plasma reagin test is used to test for syphilis, which is more common in individuals who do not use barrier contraception and can also manifest with neurological symptoms. Tabes dorsalis, a late stage of neurosyphilis, is associated with sensory disturbances, impaired gait, bladder dysfunction, and absent deep tendon reflexes but these findings typically occur about 20 years after primary infection, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this young patient with no history of syphilis. Early manifestations of neurosyphilis include acute meningitis and ischemic stroke, none of which were reported here.

D) CORRECT:

MRI of the brain and spine is the investigation of choice for a definitive diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS). MRI typically shows multiple asymmetric white matter lesions with finger-like radial extensions often located in the spinal cord, juxtacortical, infratentorial, and periventricular regions. If a gadolinium contrast agent is used, active lesions usually appear enhanced up to 6 weeks after exacerbations. This patient most likely has relapsing-remitting MS with symptoms that correspond to lesions in the pyramidal tracts (weakness, spasticity, increased deep tendon reflexes), dorsal spinal column (loss of vibration and fine touch), and autonomic nervous system (urinary incontinence).

Absent abdominal reflex is an early and important sign of MS that is seen in about 70% of patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Electromyography can be helpful in diagnosing amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). While this patient has symptoms of upper motor neuron injury, she does not have other findings seen in patients with ALS, such as lower motor neuron injury (e.g., absent or diminished deep tendon reflexes, flaccid paralysis, atrophy, fasciculations). Moreover, patients with ALS do not experience symptom remission.
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

F) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is indicated for cases of suspected multiple sclerosis (MS) in which the first-line diagnostic test is inconclusive. In patients with MS, the cerebral spinal fluid analysis typically shows lymphocytic pleocytosis and oligoclonal bands. While this patient must be assessed for MS, she has not yet received first-line diagnostic testing.
questions.hint: The reversible exacerbation of neurological symptoms following an increase in body temperature (e.g., hot weather, warm bath, physical exertion) is referred to as Uhthoff phenomenon. This phenomenon is characteristic of a certain disease that predominantly affects women of childbearing age.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of increasing weakness and numbness of her legs for 3 days. She noticed that the weakness was more severe after she had a hot shower that morning. A year ago, she had an episode of partial vision loss in her left eye that resolved within 3 weeks. She is sexually active with 3 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. She appears anxious. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 108/77 mm Hg. Examination shows spasticity and decreased muscle strength in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response bilaterally. The abdominal reflex is absent. Sensation to vibration and position over the lower extremities shows no abnormalities. Tandem gait is impaired. MRI of the brain and spine is inconclusive. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Oligoclonal bands in cerebral spinal fluid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A positive rapid plasma reagin test is a nonspecific laboratory finding that is associated with syphilis, which can manifest with a variety of neurologic symptoms if the infection is chronic and untreated (tertiary syphilis). While this patient is at risk for syphilis given her sexual history (multiple partners with inconsistent barrier use), neurosyphilis typically occurs decades after infection and is often triggered by immunosuppression (e.g., HIV infection). Moreover, symptoms would be chronic and progressive, whereas this patient's visual symptoms have resolved.

B) INCORRECT:

Peripheral nerve demyelination can be seen in multiple neurological disorders such as Guillain Barré syndrome, which may also cause weakness and sensory changes. However, this patient has evidence of upper motor neuron damage (hyperreflexia, extensor Babinski response), so her disease is localized to the CNS. Moreover, demyelination in patients with MS only occurs within the CNS.

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of fasciculations on electromyography indicates spontaneous nerve activity and is commonly seen in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and other anterior horn degenerative diseases. This patient has MS, which is characterized by slow nerve conduction velocity (seen in up to 70% of cases).

D) INCORRECT:

An elevated intrinsic factor antibody level is part of the diagnosis of pernicious anemia, which can manifest with bilateral lower extremity sensorimotor changes (i.e., subacute combined degeneration), upper motor neuron signs, and rarely, visual changes. However, the relapsing remitting course of this patient's disease suggests an alternative cause of her symptoms. If vitamin B12 deficiency was the cause of her symptoms, this patient's visual disturbance would likely not have self-resolved and would have occurred simultaneously with her sensorimotor symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

The presence of oligoclonal bands in CSF (and their absence in the blood) is highly suggestive of multiple sclerosis (MS). Lumbar puncture is indicated in patients with clinically suspected MS and inconclusive findings on MRI. Other typical findings on CSF examination include lymphocytic pleocytosis and increased myelin basic protein levels. The appearance of oligoclonal bands in the early stages of the disease indicates a poor prognosis.

F) INCORRECT:

ELISA is a highly sensitive and specific test to detect HIV infection, which can cause a variety of neurologic symptoms, including weakness, upper motor neuron signs, sensory changes, and visual disturbances. While this patient's sexual history puts her at risk for HIV infection, only patients with HIV-associated dementia would have such extensive HIV destruction of the CNS to cause this constellation of symptoms together. This patient has no evidence of dementia.
questions.hint: Relapsing remitting central neurologic symptoms, especially in a woman of childbearing age, are concerning for multiple sclerosis (MS). This patient's visual changes that resolved without treatment likely represent optic neuritis, the most common first manifestation of MS. Hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign, and absent abdominal reflex are signs of upper motor neuron dysfunction. Worsening of symptoms following a hot shower is referred to as Uhthoff phenomenon.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vision impairment in her right eye for the past 2 weeks. During this period, she was unable to distinguish colors with her right eye. She also reports pain with eye movement. She has no double vision. She occasionally has headaches that are relieved with ibuprofen. One year ago, she had a similar episode that affected her left eye and resolved spontaneously. She has no history of serious illness. She works at a library and enjoys reading, even in poor lighting conditions. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows that the right and left pupils do not constrict when a light is shone into the right eye. When light is shone into the left eye, both pupils constrict. Without correction, visual acuity is 20/50 in the left eye, and 20/100 in the right eye. With spectacles, the visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye and 20/100 in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination shows no abnormalities. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Open-angle glaucoma would typically present in patients > 40 years old with painless, slowly progressive scotomas and/or a decrease in visual acuity. A different diagnosis should be considered in this 33-year-old woman with two episodes of painful loss of vision that had complete remission a year in between.

B) INCORRECT:

Retinal detachment typically results in sudden, painless, visual field defects or complete loss of vision in the affected eye and is usually preceded by prodromal symptoms such as floaters and/or photopsia. The presence of only defective color vision and moderately decreased visual acuity, as well as the presence of pain, make the diagnosis of retinal detachment extremely unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Retinitis pigmentosa leads to a progressive loss of vision in both eyes and the initial clinical manifestations are night-blindness and decreased peripheral vision. This patient has developed acute visual impairment in one eye and has no difficulty reading in a poorly lit environment.

D) INCORRECT:

Angle-closure glaucoma manifests acutely with eye pain and a decrease in visual acuity. However, other clinical features such as photophobia, nausea, vomiting, corneal cloudiness, congestion of the ciliary and conjunctival vessels, and a fixed, semi-dilated pupil are not seen in this patient. Moreover, slit lamp examination in angle-closure glaucoma shows a shallow anterior chamber.

E) INCORRECT:

Common causes of macular degeneration include age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and myopic macular degeneration. AMD usually occurs in people > 60 years old and presents with a slowly progressive, painless, bilateral decrease in visual acuity. Myopic macular degeneration may occur in younger patients and would also present with an insidious, painless loss of vision but is seen in patients with pathological myopia. Patients with pathological myopia would have a deep anterior chamber on slit lamp examination, and an uncorrected visual acuity that is far worse than 20/200 in both eyes.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with optic neuritis, which is often the first manifestation of multiple sclerosis (MS). MS is more common in women than men and it typically manifests at 20–40 years of age, with a relapsing-remitting clinical pattern. Most patients with optic neuritis have a relative afferent pupillary defect and a normal fundus on ophthalmoscopy.

All patients who present with new-onset optic neuritis should undergo a brain MRI to assess for demyelinating plaques, which support a diagnosis of MS.
questions.hint: This 33-year-old female patient presents with acute, unilateral color blindness, a decrease in visual acuity, and pain with eye movements, all of which are consistent with a specific diagnosis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Two years ago, she was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. She has had 4 exacerbations over the past 6 months. Three weeks ago, she was admitted and treated for right lower leg weakness with high-dose methylprednisone for 5 days. Current medications include interferon beta and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg. Examination shows pallor of the right optic disc. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. The patient is anxious about the number of exacerbations and repeated hospitalizations. She is counseled about other treatment options available for her condition. She agrees to start treatment with natalizumab but is concerned about potential adverse effects. If treated with natalizumab, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Drugs that are commonly associated with syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) include cyclophosphamide, SSRIs, and carbamazepine. With the exception of cyclophosphamide, which may be considered in secondary progressive MS that is poorly responsive to first-line disease modifying therapy, none of the aforementioned drugs are used as disease-modifying therapy in patients with MS. This patient has relapsing remitting MS and has consented to treatment with natalizumab, which is not typically associated with SIADH.

B) CORRECT:

Treatment with natalizumab increases the risk of developing progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), a demyelinating disease of the CNS caused by the reactivation of the JC virus (JCV). About 80% of the general population has a latent JCV infection, but PML is prevented by immune cells within the CNS. Natalizumab decreases the migration of lymphocytes to the CNS and thus increases the risk of PML. Given the potentially fatal nature of PML, natalizumab should be discontinued at the first sign or symptom suggestive of this condition (e.g., focal neurological deficits, seizures, hemianopsia).

Risk factors for developing PML include the presence of anti-JCV antibodies, prior immunosuppressive therapy, and a duration of natalizumab therapy > 2 years.

C) INCORRECT:

Drugs that are commonly associated with parkinsonism include dopamine antagonists such as antipsychotics and metoclopramide. Drug-induced parkinsonism is not a known complication of natalizumab.

D) INCORRECT:

Reactivation of latent tuberculosis is a known adverse effect of immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., with anti-TNF-α antibodies). However, natalizumab is not usually associated with this complication.

E) INCORRECT:

Aplastic anemia can occur in patients with MS who receive mitoxantrone as a part of disease-modifying therapy. Mitoxantrone can result in bone marrow suppression and acute myeloid leukemia. Natalizumab typically does not cause aplastic anemia or significant bone marrow suppression.

F) INCORRECT:

Drugs commonly associated with pulmonary fibrosis include bleomycin, cyclophosphamide, amiodarone, procainamide, and nitrofurantoin. With the exception of cyclophosphamide, which may be considered in secondary progressive MS that is poorly responsive to first-line disease-modifying therapy, none of the aforementioned drugs are used to treat MS. This patient has relapsing remitting MS and has consented to treatment with natalizumab, which is not typically associated with pulmonary fibrosis.

G) INCORRECT:

Drugs commonly associated with gingival hyperplasia include phenytoin, cyclosporin, and certain calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine, verapamil, diltiazem). None of these drugs are used to treat MS. Gingival hyperplasia is not a typical side effect of therapy with natalizumab.
questions.hint: While natalizumab is highly effective in the treatment of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (MS), it is also associated with a risk of developing a potentially fatal condition.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician for intermittent stabbing face pain. The pain typically occurs in waves of several individual episodes lasting about 1 second. It is bilateral, but rarely occurs on both sides simultaneously. Touching her face or brushing her teeth can trigger an attack. Four months ago, she had an episode of weakness in her right arm that lasted for 1 week. Family history is notable for migrainous headaches in her mother and brother. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is decreased sensation in the V2 and V3 distribution of the trigeminal nerve bilaterally. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the left upper extremity and 5/5 in the right upper extremity. There is spasticity of the lower extremities with sustained clonus. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Enhancing lesion in the internal auditory canal
Jaw claudication and unilateral vision loss
Erythematous papules in the V2/V3 nerve distribution

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An enhancing lesion in the internal auditory canal is the typical MRI finding of an acoustic neuroma. Although acoustic neuromas can cause trigeminal neuralgia and/or deficits in the cranial nerve V (due to compression), this patient does not have any of the classic features of acoustic neuroma such as tinnitus, hearing loss, dizziness, and/or vertigo. Moreover, this patient's history of multifocal neurological deficits raises concern for a different condition.
Image Description:

Acoustic neuromas are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells and primarily originate within the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. The tumor originates within the internal acoustic canal with variable extension into the cerebellopontine angle. Early symptoms occur due to pressure on the cochlear nerve (unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus) and vestibular nerve (dizziness, unsteady gait, disequilibrium). If the tumor further expands into the cerebellopontine angle, further symptoms arise due to compression of CN V (paresthesia, hypoesthesia, unilateral facial pain), CN VII (unilateral facial weakness), and the cerebellum (ataxia).

B) INCORRECT:

Jaw claudication and unilateral vision loss are seen in giant cell arteritis, which is rarely seen in patients under 50 years of age. In addition, the pain related to giant cell arteritis is typically a pulse-synchronous, throbbing, dull headache over the temples rather than the paroxysmal, severe stabbing facial pain of trigeminal neuralgia seen in this patient. Moreover, this patient's history of multifocal neurological deficits raises concern for a different condition.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's bilateral trigeminal neuralgia is likely due to demyelination of the trigeminal nerve nuclei secondary to the progression of multiple sclerosis (MS). Patients with MS typically develop episodic, multifocal neurological deficits due to demyelination at multiple sites of the CNS. Multiple periventricular sclerotic plaques are typically seen on MRI in patients with MS as a result of reactive gliosis (reactive hyperplasia of neuroglial cells like astrocytes) following demyelination.

Acute MS exacerbations are treated with high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone. The treatment of trigeminal neuralgia due to MS is identical to the treatment of classic trigeminal neuralgia (e.g., carbamazepine).
Image Description:

MRI Brain (FLAIR; axial view)

There are periventricular areas of linear and ovoid hyperintense signal orientated perpendicular to the body of the right lateral ventricle (green overlay).

This feature is known as Dawson fingers and is strongly associated with multiple sclerosis. It represents perivascular inflammation around the subependymal veins.

D) INCORRECT:

Erythematous papules in the V2/V3 trigeminal nerve distribution occur in herpes zoster, which can manifest with burning, throbbing, or stabbing pain limited to a dermatome. However, this patient's history of multifocal neurological deficits raises concern for a different condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Photophobia and phonophobia are associated with migraine headaches. Although the pathophysiology is unclear, migraines tend to occur after a trigger, last 4–72 hours, and are typically unilateral. Motor function loss is seen in rare causes of hemiplegic migraine, but patients tend to recover within 24 hours. The short duration of this patient's headaches and associated neurological findings raise concern for a different diagnosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Rhinorrhea, lacrimation, and ptosis can be seen as a result of autonomic activation associated with cluster headaches. Unlike this patient's presentation, cluster headaches typically manifest with episodes of severe periorbital or temporal pain that last 15–180 minutes. Episodes are always unilateral but separate episodes can occur bilaterally as seen in this patient. However, cluster headaches do not cause weakness, numbness or spasticity. Additionally, they mostly affect men.
questions.hint: Triggerable stabbing face pain is consistent with trigeminal neuralgia. Additionally, this patient's episodic multifocal neurological deficits (weakness, numbness, spasticity) raise concern for a demyelinating process.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis 1 year ago. She has had two exacerbations since then, each lasting 1 week and each requiring hospitalization for corticosteroid treatment. Her most recent exacerbation was 3 weeks ago. She has had no neurological symptoms between exacerbations. She takes a multivitamin and a calcium supplement daily. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination, including neurological examination, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interferon beta (IFN beta) rather than interferon alpha (IFN alpha) is used in the management of MS. IFN beta can be used in the long-term management of most forms of MS to prevent relapses. It prevents exacerbations of MS by downregulating the expression of major histocompatibility complex molecules on antigen-presenting cells, inhibiting T-cell proliferation, and decreasing the level of proinflammatory cytokines while increasing the level of regulatory cytokines. IFN alpha is FDA-approved to treat hairy cell leukemia, chronic hepatitis C, and chronic myelogenous leukemia, but not MS.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitoxantrone is used as a second-line or third-line disease-modifying drug for relapsing-remitting MS when the number of exacerbations is not controlled by first-line drugs. Mitoxantrone is not used as a first-line drug because of its association with cardiotoxicity and immunosuppression.

C) INCORRECT:

Methylprednisolone is used to treat acute relapses of MS, but it is not effective at preventing relapses.

D) CORRECT:

Monoclonal antibodies (e.g., natalizumab, ocrelizumab) have the highest efficacy for reducing exacerbations of MS. Natalizumab can be used in most forms of MS to prevent relapses. It binds to integrin receptors on endothelial cells, which prevents integrins from binding to these receptors (and consequently trigger leukocyte chemotaxis to the site of inflammation). In patients with MS, natalizumab binds the alpha-4-integrin receptors and inhibits lymphocyte invasion of the central nervous system. Natalizumab has been associated with an increased risk of developing progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy and patients should, therefore, be carefully monitored.

Other medications that can be used as first-line disease-modifying drugs in relapsing-remitting MS include interferon beta, glatiramer acetate, dimethyl fumarate, teriflunomide, and fingolimod. The adverse effects profile should be taken into consideration when selecting medications for patients: lower efficacy medications (e.g., interferon beta, glatiramer acetate) often have fewer side effects than monoclonal antibodies.

E) INCORRECT:

Supportive therapy is indicated for symptomatic relief in patients with spasticity (e.g., baclofen, physiotherapy), painful paresthesias (e.g., carbamazepine, amitriptyline), urinary retention (e.g., intermittent catheterization), and/or urinary incontinence (e.g., oxybutynin). This patient is in remission; rather than give supportive therapy only as needed, a disease-modifying drug should be initiated to decrease the occurrence of exacerbations.
questions.hint: This patient has relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (MS) based on multiple episodes of neurological symptoms with a complete return to baseline in between. This asymptomatic period is an ideal time to start her on a first-line agent for long-term treatment of her condition.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent painful double vision for the past 3 days. Her symptoms occur only when looking sideways. She has myopia and has been wearing corrective lenses for 10 years. Ten days ago, she lost her balance and fell off her bike, for which she went to a hospital. A CT scan of the head at that time showed no abnormalities and she was released without further treatment. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Vital signs are within normal limits. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Her best corrected visual acuity is 20/40 in each eye. She has an adduction deficit in the right eye and horizontal nystagmus in the left eye when looking left; she has an adduction deficit in the left eye and horizontal nystagmus in the right eye when looking right. Convergence testing shows no abnormalities. Fundoscopy shows bilateral disc hyperemia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

choices.text: Demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus
Oxidative damage due to thiamine deficiency
Subdural hematoma extending into the orbit

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Caudal displacement of the cerebellar vermis occurs in patients with Chiari II malformation, a condition that usually causes hydrocephalus secondary to stenosis of the aqueduct of Sylvius and may cause cerebellar signs (e.g., ataxia). While this patient has signs of balance problems, Chiari II malformation is almost always seen in conjunction with a lumbosacral or thoracic meningomyelocele, so it is often detected at birth. Based on her history alone, this adult patient is very unlikely to have this diagnosis. Moreover, Chiari II malformation does not cause INO.

B) CORRECT:

Bilateral INO, optic neuritis, and ataxia (loss of balance) in a young woman should raise concern for multiple sclerosis (MS). In MS, demyelination of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) can lead to INO. In younger patients, MS is the most common cause of INO. In older patients (especially those with arteriosclerotic risk factors), INO is more commonly caused by ischemic infarction and manifests with unilateral findings and additional stroke findings. All patients with INO should undergo MRI of the brain.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibodies against acetylcholine receptors cause myasthenia gravis (MG). MG may manifest initially with painless diplopia and ptosis due to ocular muscle fatigue, which is characteristically worse at the end of the day or with exercise. While this patient has diplopia, MG would not cause this patient's horizontal gaze abnormality or eye pain.
Image Description:

AChR: acetylcholine receptor; Anti-AChR-Ab: acetylcholine receptor antibody; VGCC-Ab: voltage-gated calcium channel antibody

D) INCORRECT:

A compressive tumor in the pons (e.g., pontine glioma) may cause bilateral INO if it compresses the structure responsible for conjugate horizontal gaze. Furthermore, this patient's episode of balance difficulties is consistent with a brainstem tumor. However, it would be rare for these tumors to cause INO in isolation, as they usually also cause additional cranial nerve abnormalities (e.g., dysarthria, dysphagia, facial sensory loss) and other neurological changes (ataxia and upper motor neuron lesions). Finally, brainstem gliomas are much more common in individuals under the age of 20 years.

E) INCORRECT:

Oxidative damage due to thiamine deficiency is the underlying mechanism of Wernicke encephalopathy, a condition that causes ophthalmoplegia and balance difficulties. However, this condition usually presents with more severe cognitive symptoms such as delirium and occurs primarily in patients with alcohol use disorder and/or those with nutritional deficiencies, neither of which is seen in this patient. Though the ophthalmoplegia seen in Wernicke encephalopathy may be similar to INO, it usually causes lateral gaze nystagmus without adduction difficulties.

F) INCORRECT:

Subdural hematomas can cause elevated intracranial pressure and headache following traumatic injury. Most cases of subdural hematoma cause headaches, confusion, nausea, or vomiting several days to weeks after trauma, none of which are seen in this patient. Although INO caused by subdural hematomas have been described in case reports, it is an exceedingly rare phenomenon, especially in a patient without any other signs of subdural hematoma (e.g., altered mental status, headache).

G) INCORRECT:

Brainstem infarction is the most common cause of INO in older patients. It is most likely in patients with vascular risk factors (e.g., obesity, smoking, factor V Leiden) and usually causes unilateral, not bilateral, INO with other stroke findings (e.g., unilateral hemiparesis, cranial nerve abnormalities). This patient has a very low risk of stroke, and another cause of INO is more likely.
questions.hint: Impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye and abduction nystagmus of the contralateral eye (i.e., dissociated nystagmus) on lateral horizontal gaze should raise concern for internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO), in which convergence is usually preserved. This patient's findings are consistent with bilateral INO. In addition, painful eye movements and hyperemia of the optic discs suggest optic neuritis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-day history of intermittent dizziness and double vision. She reports double vision whenever she looks to the left. Last summer, she had an episode of weakness in her left leg that resolved spontaneously. Ophthalmologic examination shows weak adduction of the right eye on left lateral gaze. Attempted left lateral gaze results in horizontal nystagmus of the left eye. Convergence testing is normal. This patient most likely has a lesion in which of the following labeled areas of the schematic overview of a transverse section of the midbrain?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The right superior colliculus integrates visual, auditory, and somatosensory information with motor signals. This structure allows the orientation of the head towards stimuli. However, injury of the right superior colliculus would result in the inability to turn the head reflexively towards the left upon sensory stimulation from that side; it would not result in the impaired coordination of the eyes during lateral gaze.

B) INCORRECT:

The left superior colliculus integrates visual, auditory, and somatosensory information with motor signals. This structure allows the orientation of the head towards stimuli. However, injury of the left superior colliculus would result in the inability to turn the head reflexively towards the right upon sensory stimulation from that side; it would not result in the impaired coordination of the eyes during lateral gaze.

C) CORRECT:

The medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) connects the nucleus of the CN VI (which controls ocular abduction) to the contralateral nucleus of the CN III (which controls ocular adduction). This connection allows for the coordination of both eyes during lateral gaze. Lesions in the MLF, such as those found in multiple sclerosis, disrupt adduction of the eye ipsilateral to the lesion, causing nystagmus in the contralateral eye as diplopia causes it to readjust.

D) INCORRECT:

Lesions in the left medial longitudinal fasciculus would cause internuclear ophthalmoplegia. However, double vision would occur on right lateral gaze, not left lateral gaze as seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

The red nucleus is a large structure within the rostral midbrain that receives input from various motor areas, particularly the deep cerebellar nuclei. Lesions of the red nucleus can result in extensor posturing, with extension of both upper and lower extremities. However, lesions of the red nucleus do not cause an impaired coordination of the eyes during lateral gaze.

F) INCORRECT:

The red nucleus is a large structure within the rostral midbrain that receives input from motor areas, particularly the deep cerebellar nuclei. Lesions of the red nucleus can result in extensor posturing, with the extension of both upper and lower extremities. However, lesions of the red nucleus do not cause an impaired coordination of the eyes during lateral gaze.

G) INCORRECT:

Lesions of the right oculomotor nerve would impair the function of the medial rectus, which would, in turn, impair the adduction of the right eye, similar to this patient. However, complete palsy of the nerve would mean that the right eye would be in a down-and-out position and would fail to converge. Thus, nystagmus would not be found.

H) INCORRECT:

Lesions of the left oculomotor nerve would impair the function of the medial rectus, impairing adduction of the ipsilateral left eye. However, palsy of the left CN III would leave the left eye in a down-and-out position, without the ability to converge and with no nystagmus. Adduction of the right eye on left lateral gaze would not be impaired.
questions.hint: Impaired horizontal eye movements with weak adduction of one eye and abduction nystagmus of the contralateral eye are indicative of internuclear ophthalmoplegia, which results from a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus. In this young woman with a previous episode of neurologic dysfunction, the most likely cause of the lesion is multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing weakness in both legs for 7 days. She also reports a tingling sensation in her legs that is exacerbated by taking a hot shower. She is sexually active with one male partner and does not use condoms. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F). Physical examination shows decreased muscle strength and clonus in both lower extremities. Patellar reflex is 4+ bilaterally and plantar reflex shows an extensor response on both sides. Abdominal reflex is absent. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following findings is most likely to further support the diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Positive antibody response to cardiolipin-cholesterol-lecithin antigen in the serum
Oligodendrocytes that stain positive for polyomavirus proteins on brain biopsy
Presence of immunoglobulin bands on cerebrospinal fluid immunofixation
Identification of gram-positive cocci in groups on blood culture
Detection of high-affinity antibodies to dsDNA in the serum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Positive antibody response to cardiolipin-cholesterol-lecithin antigen in the serum (positive rapid plasma reagin test) is a nonspecific finding in patients with syphilis. The RPR test is used to screen for syphilis as well as evaluate disease activity and monitor treatment response. Although tertiary syphilis can manifest with various neurological symptoms (neurosyphilis), it usually progresses slowly and would not be expected to show periventricular hyperintensities on MRI of the brain, as seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

A finding of oligodendrocytes that stain positive for polyomavirus proteins on brain biopsy is the hallmark of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) due to JC virus infection. PML causes progressive neurological degeneration that can mimic multiple sclerosis. Diffusion-weighted MRI images would typically show asymmetric hyperintense lesions. However, PML is most commonly associated with AIDS, which this patient has no evidence of.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a brain biopsy specimen of a patient with PML (immunohistochemistry stain; 400x magnification)

Glial cells infected with the JC (John Cunningham) virus are highlighted in dark brown.

C) CORRECT:

The presence of immunoglobulin bands (particularly oligoclonal bands) and increased IgG production in the CSF are highly sensitive, but nonspecific, findings that support the diagnosis of MS. Lumbar puncture is indicated for patients with suspected MS who have inconclusive clinical and MRI findings. The production of multiple, nonspecific clones of IgG within the CNS is a result of intrathecal inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

Identification of gram-positive cocci (GPC) in groups on blood culture would not be seen in this patient who has no signs or symptoms of sepsis (e.g., fever, chills, hypotension). In addition, her neurological symptoms and imaging cannot be explained by sepsis.

E) INCORRECT:

Detection of high-affinity antibodies to dsDNA in the serum would suggest a diagnosis of SLE, which does occur predominantly in women of childbearing age and can cause neurological symptoms. This patient, however, does not have other classical features of SLE (e.g., photosensitivity, discoid rash, oral ulcers, arthritis), making another finding more likely.
questions.hint: This patient presents with lower leg weakness, tingling sensation exacerbated by hot shower (Uhthoff phenomenon), hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign, and an absent abdominal reflex. All of these, especially in a woman of childbearing age, suggest multiple sclerosis (MS). The MRI image shows periventricular hyperintensities (T2 weighted), suggestive of demyelination.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasingly frequent episodes of double vision for 2 days. She was seen in the emergency department for an episode of imbalance and decreased sensation in her right arm 3 months ago. Examination shows impaired adduction of the right eye with left lateral gaze but normal convergence of both eyes. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ in all extremities. The Romberg test is positive. An MRI of the brain shows hyperintense oval plaques in the periventricular region and a plaque in the midbrain on T2-weighted images. Microscopic examination of material from the midbrain plaque would most likely show which of the following?

choices.text: Loss of axons and atrophy of oligodendrocytes
Demyelination with partial preservation of axons

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies within neurons, known as Lewy bodies, are typical histopathological markers of Parkinson disease, multiple system atrophy, and dementia with Lewy bodies. These diseases can manifest with postural instability. However, characteristic features of parkinsonism (bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor) would also be expected. Furthermore, it would be unusual for these diseases to manifest in a patient who is so young (typical age of onset is > 60 years).
Image Description:

Photomicrographs of a substantia nigra tissue sample (A: H&E stain, 500x magnification; B: immunochemical α-synuclein stain, 400x magnification)

Image A: An eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion (Lewy body; blue overlay) is visible inside a neuron. There is a large accumulation of neuromelanin (brown granules; green overlay).

Image B: A neurite staining positive for α-synuclein is visible in the center of the image (Lewy neurite; yellow overlay).

Lewy bodies and neurites are seen in various neurodegenerative disorders, e.g., Parkinson's disease and dementia with Lewy bodies.

B) INCORRECT:

Loss of axons and atrophy of oligodendrocytes is a sign of advanced neurodegeneration. It can be seen on microscopic examination of older (chronic) lesions in multiple sclerosis. Here, however, in this patient, the tissue is taken from the acute midbrain plaque, where those longterm damages would not yet be evident.

C) INCORRECT:

Lymphocytic infiltration of the endoneurium resulting in myelin damage is a typical finding in Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), which typically presents with ascending paralysis, reduced or absent muscle reflexes, peripheral, symmetric paresthesias in the hands and feet, and neuropathic pain. Furthermore, GBS typically appears after a gastrointestinal or respiratory infection and would not show plaques on MRI imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Extracellular plaques composed of amyloid beta are common histopathological markers of Alzheimer disease. Patients with Alzheimer disease typically present with short-term memory loss and loss of attention control/reasoning, orientation, and language, none of which is present in this patient. Furthermore, MRI would show generalized atrophy in the CNS, most pronounced in the hippocampus and/or medial temporal lobe. Additionally, it would be unusual for the disease to manifest in a patient who is so young (typical age of onset is > 65 years).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cerebral cortical tissue (H&E stain and anti-amyloid beta precursor protein immunostaining)

Multiple large red-brown extracellular structures are visible within the cortical matter. These are beta-amyloid plaques that have taken up the immunostain.

Accumulation of amyloid plaques in the interneuronal spaces of the brain is a characteristic feature of Alzheimer disease.

E) CORRECT:

Acute multiple sclerosis plaques are characterized by demyelination with partial preservation of axons, along with immune cell infiltration, accumulation of macrophages with phagocytized myelin, and parenchymal edema. These changes are a result of an autoimmune reaction in which mainly T helper cells are activated against CNS antigens. This reaction can be triggered by environmental factors such as infection with EBV or HHV 6, UV radiation, insufficient vitamin D consumption, and/or cigarette smoking. The subsequent inflammatory process leads to focal demyelination with nerve destruction, gliosis, and inadequate remyelination, which, in turn, results in impaired saltatory conduction of action potentials.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a cross section of cerebral tissue (CD68 immunohistochemical stain; 10x magnification)

Numerous infiltrating macrophages (stained brown by the immunochemistry) are visible, many of which surround demyelinating axons (examples indicated by green overlay).

These features are typically seen in multiple sclerosis.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of internuclear ophthalmoplegia (diplopia, impaired adduction with intact convergence), pyramidal tract involvement (generalized hyperreflexia, imbalance), and sensory disturbance (abnormal Romberg test). Together with the MRI findings, these findings are consistent with multiple sclerosis. The plaque in the midbrain most likely corresponds to a lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus, which is responsible for her acute symptoms.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman with a history of multiple sclerosis is brought to the physician because of dizziness, urinary incontinence, loss of vision in her right eye, and numbness and weakness of the left leg. She has had recurrent episodes of neurological symptoms despite several changes in her medication regimen. An MRI of the brain shows several new enhancing lesions in the periventricular white matter and the brainstem. Treatment with a drug that binds to CD52 is initiated. Which of the following agents was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Eculizumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds complement protein C5 to prevent its cleavage to C5a and C5b. This impairs formation of the membrane attack complex. Eculizumab is used in the treatment of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria because it reduces intravascular hemolysis. It does not bind CD52 glycoproteins and would not be indicated as a treatment for this patient's multiple sclerosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds VEGF receptors and is used to treat neovascular age-related macular degeneration, colorectal cancer, and renal cell carcinoma. This antibody does not target CD52 glycoproteins and would not be the treatment of choice in this patient with a history of multiple sclerosis.

C) CORRECT:

Alemtuzumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that targets cells expressing CD52 glycoproteins on their surface (T cells, B cells, NKT cells, and monocytes). Eliminating these cells limits immune-mediated injury to oligodendrocytes. Alemtuzumab is used to treat refractory multiple sclerosis (MS), which is consistent with this patient's history of persistent MS symptoms that have failed to respond to various medication regimes.

D) INCORRECT:

Rituximab is a humanized monoclonal antibody that causes the depletion of cells that express CD20 glycoproteins on their surface (B lymphocytes). Rituximab is used to treat rheumatoid arthritis, immune thrombocytopenic purpura, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and symptomatic Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia. It does not bind CD52 glycoproteins and would not be the treatment of choice in this patient with a history of refractory multiple sclerosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Omalizumab is an anti-IgE monoclonal antibody that binds free and B-cell membrane-bound IgE. It is used in the treatment of moderate to severe allergic asthma, which is associated with high levels of IgE and is refractory to treatment with inhaled steroids and long-acting β2-agonists. Omalizumab does not bind CD52 glycoproteins and would not be the treatment of choice in this patient with a history of refractory multiple sclerosis.

F) INCORRECT:

Natalizumab is a recombinant monoclonal antibody that targets integrin alpha-4 surface subunits on inflammatory lymphocytes and monocytes, impairing the ability of cells to adhere to blood vessels and preventing auto-inflammation. This antibody is used to treat multiple sclerosis, but it is not the drug prescribed to this patient because it does not target CD52 glycoproteins.
questions.hint: CD52 is a surface glycoprotein expressed on mature lymphocytes. Treatment with the monoclonal antibody that binds to CD52 is used in cases of refractory multiple sclerosis (MS) and B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man with multiple sclerosis comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. After evaluation, the physician recommends the administration of baclofen to the patient. This drug is most likely to improve which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sudden, painful paresthesias of the face, trunk, and limbs can occur in patients with MS due to involvement of the brainstem and dorsal spinal column. Baclofen may cause paresthesias, so it is not used to treat this symptom. MS-associated paresthesias are usually treated with carbamazepine and amitriptyline.

B) CORRECT:

By activating the GABAB receptors, baclofen decreases excitatory neurotransmitter release and lessens γ motor neuron excitability, which improves spasticity, a common problem in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS). In individuals with MS, spasticity can cause impaired walking, make it harder to perform activities of daily living, and worsen fatigue. The aim of treatment for spasticity in patients with MS is to decrease muscle tone enough that function improves, but not reduce it to the point that safety is decreased. Baclofen is a supportive therapy (rather than a disease-modifying drug) for MS and can be administered either orally or intrathecally via a pump.

Other spasticity treatments include physiotherapy, dantrolene, and tizanidine.

C) INCORRECT:

Individuals with MS commonly have comorbid depression. Some of the factors that contribute to depression in patients with MS are anxiety, cognitive impairment, excessive sleepiness, sexual dysfunction, and urinary incontinence. MS patients with depression are treated with psychotherapy and antidepressants (SSRIs, SNRIs, TCAs, or bupropion) instead of baclofen.

D) INCORRECT:

Erectile dysfunction is common in men with MS. Since autonomic dysfunction contributes to erectile dysfunction (and GABA is not involved), there would not be a role for baclofen in the treatment of this issue. Erectile dysfunction is treated with phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil).

E) INCORRECT:

MS is associated with bladder problems such as urinary incontinence, which is caused by detrusor overactivity due to impairment of the detrusor reflex. Since GABA is not involved, there would not be a role for baclofen in the treatment of urinary incontinence. MS-associated urinary incontinence is treated with antimuscarinic agents (e.g., oxybutynin).

F) INCORRECT:

MS is associated with bladder problems such as urinary retention. Since autonomic dysfunction contributes to the urinary retention (and GABA is not involved), there would not be a role for baclofen in the treatment of this issue. MS-associated urinary retention is treated with intermittent catheterization and parasympathomimetic drugs (e.g., bethanechol).
questions.hint: Baclofen, a centrally acting γ-aminobutyric acid B (GABAB) receptor agonist, exerts its effect on receptors in the brainstem and in the spinal cord's dorsal horn.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 6-hour history of urinary incontinence as well as a 7-day history of progressive weakness and a tingling sensation in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. He had a mild respiratory tract infection approximately 1 month ago but has no personal or family history of serious illness. He is sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He takes no medications. He drinks 2 glasses of wine on the weekends, smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but quit 1 year ago, and does not use illicit drugs. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. On examination, cranial nerves are intact. Muscle strength is 3/5 in both the upper and lower extremities. Babinski sign is present. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ throughout. Sensation to pinprick, light touch, temperature, and vibration are decreased in all extremities and the trunk up to the clavicle; sensation above the clavicle is normal. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding?

choices.text: Positive titers on a rapid plasma reagin test
Decreased peripheral nerve conduction velocity on an electrophysiological examination
Increased methylmalonic acid concentration on serum analysis
Anterior nerve root enhancement on spinal MRI

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Positive titers on a rapid plasma reagin test suggest syphilis, which may occur in a patient with risky sexual behavior. Bladder dysfunction can occur due to tabes dorsalis, a neurological manifestation of tertiary syphilis. However, tabes dorsalis usually progresses slowly and exclusively affects the dorsal columns, so only sensation to vibration and light touch is lost. Moreover, hyporeflexia or areflexia (rather than hyperreflexia) is expected in tabes dorsalis because the afferent reflex pathways are compromised.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased peripheral nerve conduction velocity is common in Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), which is associated with recent infection and acute progression of symptoms. However, involvement of lower limbs is most likely to be more pronounced than upper limb involvement, a clear sensory level is not expected, and autonomic impairment typically manifests as cardiovascular instability rather than bowel/bladder dysfunction. Moreover, GBS results in a lower motor neuron lesion, so affected individuals do not present with a positive Babinski sign or hyperreflexia but with hyporeflexia or areflexia. The peripheral nerves are not affected in TM.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased methylmalonic acid concentration is a finding in patients with vitamin B12 deficiency, which can cause subacute combined degeneration and/or peripheral neuropathy and thereby manifest with weakness, urinary incontinence, and sensory loss. However, the onset of symptoms due to vitamin B12 deficiency typically occurs over months to years and this patient has no known risk factors for vitamin B12 deficiency (e.g., chronic heavy alcohol use, malnutrition, malabsorption, atrophic gastritis, previous gastrectomy).

D) CORRECT:

Pleocytosis and/or a raised IgG index on cerebrospinal fluid analysis are typical findings in TM and indicate its inflammatory etiology. MRI of the spinal cord often shows a focal contrast-enhancing intramedullary lesion affecting contiguous spinal cord segments but can be normal in approx. one-third of patients with TM. Further diagnostic workup aims to determine the cause of TM, which can be idiopathic (usually as a postinfectious complication), an autoimmune neurological condition (e.g., multiple sclerosis, neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorders), a systemic inflammatory autoimmune disorder (e.g., sarcoidosis, systemic lupus erythematosus), or paraneoplastic syndromes.

TM is treated with high-dose IV glucocorticoids and, if the response to glucocorticoids is insufficient, with plasmapheresis and/or IV cyclophosphamide. Treatment of the underlying condition is also required in patients with secondary TM. The prognosis of TM is variable; approx. two-thirds of patients with TM recover completely over 1–3 months and in the remainder of cases, neurological deficits reverse partially over several years or persist permanently.

See "Clinical features of Guillain-Barré syndrome vs. transverse myelitis" table.
Image Description:

MRI cervical and thoracic spine (T2-weighted; sagittal plane) of a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus and sudden onset quadriplegia

Longitudinal hyperintensity within the spinal cord (green overlay), extending from C2 to T2, reflects edema of the spinal cord.

E) INCORRECT:

Anterior nerve root enhancement on spinal MRI is common in Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), which is associated with recent infection and acute progression of symptoms. However, involvement of lower limbs is most likely to be more pronounced than upper limb involvement, a clear sensory level is not expected, and autonomic impairment typically manifests as cardiovascular instability rather than bowel/bladder dysfunction. Moreover, GBS results in a lower motor neuron lesion, so affected individuals do not present with a positive Babinski sign or hyperreflexia but with hyporeflexia or areflexia. The nerve roots are not affected in transverse myelitis.
Image Description:

MRI thoracic spine (T1-weighted fat-saturated, axial plane, with contrast)

Enhancement of a right-sided anterior nerve root (arrowhead) is demonstrated at the level of the thoracic spine.

This is an example of Guillain-Barré-syndrome (GBS). Although MRI scans can be normal in patients with GBS, enhancement of the conus medullaris and/or the nerve roots of the cauda equina can be demonstrated on contrast-enhanced MRI scans. Differential diagnoses for nerve root enhancement include infection, trauma (such as from an extruded disk), or neoplasia.
questions.hint: This patient's findings of a recent infection followed by features of a spinal cord lesion (urinary incontinence, hyperreflexia, a positive Babinski sign, bilateral weakness. sensory loss) with an identifiable sensory level (symmetrical sensation loss up to the clavicle) are in keeping with transverse myelitis (TM).

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman reports double vision that has worsened during the past 2 days. Six months ago, she experienced 3 weeks of numbness and tingling in the right arm and leg that resolved within a month, although she did not seek medical evaluation at the time. On examination now, she is unable to adduct her left eye.
MRI of the brain is performed (figure).
Which one of the following cerebrospinal fluid findings is most likely for this patient?

choices.text: Positive polymerase-chain-reaction test for Epstein-Barr virus
Clonal B-cell population on flow cytometry

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A low CSF glucose level is typical of bacterial, tuberculous, or fungal CNS infections but not of multiple sclerosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated CSF 14-3-3 protein occurs in patients with Creutzfeldt-Jakob or other neurodegenerative diseases.

C) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) does not lead to a positive Epstein-Barr virus polymerase-chain-reaction test of the CSF, although prior Epstein-Barr virus infection may be a risk factor for MS.

D) INCORRECT:

A clonal B-cell population in the CSF on flow cytometry would raise concern for CNS lymphoma.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is consistent with multiple sclerosis (MS). MS typically occurs in a young or middle-aged adult with variable episodes of neurologic dysfunction involving different parts of the central nervous system (CNS). This patient recently experienced a hemisensory syndrome and now presents with abnormal eye movements. The inability to adduct one eye, termed an internuclear ophthalmoplegia, is common in MS patients.

MRI of the brain shows multiple ovoid white-matter lesions, particularly clustered around the ventricles. The MRI appearance in this clinical context is consistent with MS.

In about 85% of MS patients, the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows oligoclonal bands on a protein electrophoresis gel that are present only in the CSF and not in the blood. These bands represent intrathecally synthesized immunoglobulins. An elevated ratio of the level of immunoglobulin G (IgG) in the CSF relative to that in the blood (the IgG index) is also common in MS patients. The specificity of oligoclonal bands is suboptimal, as they may be present in cases of infection. However, this patient’s presentation is more consistent with MS than an infection, and oligoclonal bands remain the most useful diagnostic test of CSF and blood presently available.

Key learning point: The cerebrospinal fluid finding characteristic of multiple sclerosis is oligoclonal bands (multiple bands on protein electrophoresis gel that are present in the cerebrospinal fluid but not in the blood).

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis presents with leg numbness and weakness that, during the past 2 days, has progressed up both her legs to her lower abdomen. She reports difficulty walking and urinary hesitancy.
Physical examination reveals moderate paraparesis, hyperreflexia in the legs, and numbness up to the T12 level. The patient is hospitalized, and MRI shows a gadolinium-enhanced lesion in the upper thoracic spinal cord.
Which one of the following acute treatments is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral azathioprine is not used to treat multiple sclerosis relapses.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulin is not typically used to manage acute multiple sclerosis exacerbations, although it is used to treat other conditions, including acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (Guillain-Barré syndrome).

C) CORRECT:

Acute inflammatory multiple sclerosis (MS) relapses typically respond to treatment with high-dose glucocorticoids, such as methylprednisolone. No consensus exists about the optimal treatment duration or dose, but a typical regimen is intravenous methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for 3 to 5 days. Oral treatment with high-dose prednisone may also be considered, as several studies have shown noninferiority with these regimens compared to intravenous therapy. Although treatment with high-dose glucocorticoids may shorten the duration of symptoms, studies have not demonstrated any reduction in disability at 6 months.

Key learning point: The most appropriate acute treatment for a disabling multiple sclerosis relapse is a high-dose intravenous glucocorticoid.

D) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous interferon beta-1a and intravenous natalizumab are chronic disease-modifying medications for multiple sclerosis but are not useful in treating acute relapses.

E) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous interferon beta-1a and intravenous natalizumab are chronic disease-modifying medications for multiple sclerosis but are not useful in treating acute relapses.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman presents with a 4-day history of decreased vision in her right eye. She has had no eye redness, ocular discharge, or light sensitivity. She reports no history of medical problems, and a review of systems is negative.
On examination, visual acuity is 20/400 in the right eye and 20/20 in the left eye. A right afferent pupillary defect is noted. The patient’s extraocular movements are full, but she has pronounced pain whenever she attempts to move her right eye. On funduscopic examination, the optic nerve appears normal, with crisp margins, no hemorrhages, and no cotton-wool spots.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Perform MRI of the brain and orbits, with and without contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Optic neuritis, which refers to inflammation and demyelination of the optic nerve, disproportionately affects younger women. Affected patients typically present with unilateral decreased vision, pain with extraocular movement, a relative afferent pupillary defect (the pupil dilates during the swinging-flashlight test), diminished color vision, and optic nerves that appear normal on funduscopic examination.

Optic neuritis is associated with multiple sclerosis. Consequently, any patient presenting with new-onset optic neuritis should undergo MRI of the brain and orbits, with and without contrast, to assess for T2-weighted and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery lesions consistent with multiple sclerosis. An MRI would also help rule out other causes of this clinical presentation, such as retro-orbital tumors.

In addition to undergoing MRI, patients experiencing an initial episode of unilateral optic neuritis are often admitted for treatment with intravenous glucocorticoids. They typically receive intravenous methylprednisolone for 3 days followed by an oral prednisone taper for 11 days. This approach can shorten the time to visual recovery but does not affect long-term clinical outcomes.

Key learning point: Patients presenting with a first episode of unilateral optic neuritis should undergo MRI of the brain and orbits to determine the risk for multiple sclerosis.

B) INCORRECT:

CT cannot readily detect the findings typical of multiple sclerosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral glucocorticoids have been associated with an increased risk of recurrence when not preceded by intravenous glucocorticoids and should therefore not be offered as initial treatment in this setting.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment and measurement of inflammatory activity are not indicated in cases of new-onset unilateral optic neuritis. An infectious and inflammatory workup should be considered in cases of bilateral optic neuritis or in cases of optic-nerve edema where the diagnosis is not straightforward.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment and measurement of inflammatory activity are not indicated in cases of new-onset unilateral optic neuritis. An infectious and inflammatory workup should be considered in cases of bilateral optic neuritis or in cases of optic-nerve edema where the diagnosis is not straightforward.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman with a history of depression, asthma, and chronic fatigue syndrome presents for evaluation of recent-onset monocular vision loss. She specifically describes 4 days of progressive right-sided vision loss that began when she awoke one morning. She noted a large spot in the right hemifield that has continued to enlarge. She has noticed that the color red looks less vivid than before in her right eye and that she has a lot of pain when she moves that eye. One year ago, she experienced 2 weeks of progressive gait imbalance that resolved spontaneously without any residual deficits.
On examination today, she is afebrile, and her vital signs are unremarkable. Examination of the right eye reveals visual acuity of 20/80, red color desaturation, an enlarged blind spot, and an afferent pupillary defect. The optic disk appears sharp and crisp on fundoscopy. Neurologic examination is otherwise normal. An MRI of the brain is pending.
Electrolyte levels and a complete blood count are within normal limits.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Occipital lobe stroke would manifest with hemifield vision loss in both eyes, and the affected patient would have a normal pupillary examination. Stroke would also be unlikely in an otherwise healthy 28-year-old woman.

B) INCORRECT:

Ischemic optic neuropathy is caused by ischemia to the optic nerve. Arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy occurs as a complication of arteritis, such as giant-cell arteritis, whereas nonarteritic ischemic optic neuropathy is idiopathic and occurs in the absence of arteritis, most commonly in older patients with vascular risk factors. Nonarteritic anterior ischemic neuropathy (NAION) is the most common form of ischemic optic neuropathy and affects the optic disk, whereas nonarteritic posterior ischemic neuropathy affects the retrobulbar portion of the optic nerve. The classic clinical presentation of NAION is unilateral loss of vision progressing over hours to days. Pain, as was present in this patient, would be very atypical for NAION. In addition, NAION generally manifests with optic nerve swelling (seen as blurring of the optic disk margins) on fundoscopic examination, which was absent in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with unilateral optic neuritis, a common condition found in people with multiple sclerosis (MS). Although visual field loss is the cardinal symptom of optic neuritis, pain with eye movement is another common symptom. Other typical presentations of MS include focal supratentorial syndrome, focal brainstem or cerebellar syndrome, and partial myelopathy.

Historically, MS has been diagnosed on the basis of patient-reported symptoms as well as objective clinical findings that reflect focal or multifocal inflammatory demyelinating events in the central nervous system (CNS). Diagnosis required that the patient have at least two discrete clinical events that were disseminated in time (lasting at least 24 hours each and separated by a period of at least 30 days) and also disseminated in space (with symptoms originating from at least two different CNS sites). This patient would have met the diagnostic criteria, as her prior episode of ataxia suggests a lesion in the brain or spinal cord separated in time and space from the current presentation of optic neuritis.

More recently, the diagnostic criteria for MS have been updated, and the requirement for two different neurologic events separated by 30 days has been eliminated. A diagnosis of MS can now be made in patients who have only one clinical event if they also have either (a) MRI findings demonstrating dissemination in space or (b) cerebrospinal fluid analysis demonstrating the presence of oligoclonal bands unique to the CNS.

Key learning point: The classic diagnosis of multiple sclerosis requires symptoms occurring in different parts of the central nervous system and as discrete episodes separated by at least 30 days.

D) INCORRECT:

Migraine with aura can cause some of the findings noted on this patient’s examination, but aura typically lasts no more than 60 minutes, often with coincident migraine headache. In addition, the age of onset for migraine is usually earlier than age 28, and this patient has no prior history of headaches noted.

E) INCORRECT:

Leber hereditary optic neuropathy, which is caused by an uncommon mitochondrial DNA mutation, is associated with optic neuritis that can start anywhere between 1 and 60 years of age. It can be associated with symptoms similar to those of multiple sclerosis and is diagnosed by testing for DNA point mutations. Given that approximately 90% of cases occur in males, this condition would be much less likely than multiple sclerosis in this patient.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 32-year-old woman is admitted through the emergency department (ED) for evaluation of numbness and weakness that began this morning in both legs. The onset of symptoms was accompanied by significant back pain and followed by an inability to control bladder function. The patient has had no changes in mental status, no known trauma, and no seizures or fevers. She has no cough or runny nose but does report that she had a cold about 2 weeks ago.
During physical examination, she is anxious but cooperative and conversational. Her vital signs are stable, and her cranial nerves are intact with normal visual acuity. She has 5/5 strength in both arms and shoulders, 3/5 strength in both hip flexors, and 1/5 strength in both ankles. She has normal sensation above the umbilicus but diminished sensation to light touch below the umbilicus, with no response to painful stimuli and no ability to distinguish sharp from dull stimuli in either leg. Her reflexes are 2+ in the upper extremities and absent in the lower extremities. She is unable to walk. She has no finger-nose dysmetria. Her heart, lung, abdominal, and skin examinations are unremarkable.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to yield the correct diagnosis for this patient?

choices.text: Anti-N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor antibody testing of cerebrospinal fluid

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s bilateral motor and sensory symptoms and the marked sensory level at the umbilicus, likely near T10, localize best to the spinal cord. The most common cause of such symptoms in patients with a recent cold and no history of trauma or other medical conditions is acute transverse myelitis. Spinal cord compression, an arteriovenous malformation of the spine, a spinal tumor, and an embolism to the anterior spinal artery should also be in the differential diagnosis. MRI of the spine is the best diagnostic modality to detect any of these causes and is indicated urgently in this patient.

Acute transverse myelitis, which involves an inflammatory infiltration of the spinal cord, is thought to be most commonly caused by an autoimmune reaction to a recent infection, although similar symptoms can result from direct infection of the spinal cord (e.g., by enteroviruses, influenza, varicella, mycoplasma, or other infectious agents). Transverse myelitis can cause motor, sensory, and autonomic symptoms given all the nerves that run relatively close together in the spinal cord. The presence of a marked sensory level highly suggests a spinal pathology such as transverse myelitis rather than a meningitis, encephalitis, demyelinating disorder, or disorder of the neuromuscular junction. Patients with transverse myelitis are at risk for progression of the disease, which can lead to respiratory compromise, worsening autonomic changes, and Horner syndrome.

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) studies in transverse myelitis may show a mild pleocytosis with a leukocyte count >10 cells/L (and often >50 cells/L), elevated oligoclonal bands (especially with longitudinal transverse myelitis), and an elevated immunoglobulin G index. CSF erythrocyte and glucose levels are generally normal, with an elevated or normal protein level.

Key learning point: Acute onset of pain, weakness, and numbness with a marked sensory level typically localizes to the spinal cord.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain is useful for diagnoses that can be associated with transverse myelitis (e.g., multiple sclerosis, neuromyelitis optica), but it is likely to miss the inflammation in the spinal cord that is causing this patient’s most prominent and concerning signs and symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Nerve conduction studies measure the velocity of the electrical impulse through nerves and can be useful for diagnosing a variety of neuromuscular disorders and injuries. Although some research indicates that these studies may be helpful in determining the prognosis of acute transverse myelitis or differentiating this condition from acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy, they are not part of diagnostic recommendations.

D) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography is useful to detect ongoing seizures or a postictal state. This patient has maintained a normal mental status throughout the episode, and seizures are unlikely to cause sensory findings.

E) INCORRECT:

Anti-N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor antibody testing of CSF can be used to diagnose anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis. This condition can manifest similarly to transverse myelitis, with CSF pleocytosis, autonomic instability, and motor and sensory symptoms. However, a clear sensory level is very unlikely, and affected patients generally have markedly altered mental status, which this patient does not have.

questions.text:

The onset of symptoms was accompanied by significant back pain and followed by an inability to control bladder function. The patient has had no changes in mental status, no known trauma, and no seizures or fevers. She has no cough or runny nose but does report that she had a cold about 2 weeks ago.
