questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl whose immunizations are up to date presents to the emergency department (ED) in the winter with a 2-day history of unsteady gait, low-grade fever, headache, and sleepiness. Her parents report that she was healthy until 10 days ago, when she developed a fever of 38.9°C with runny nose, cough, and congestion. Yesterday she was not able to sit up without falling over or to walk without unsteadiness. Otherwise, she has not had any falls, head trauma, or other symptoms that concerned her parents. They report that they do not have any medications in the house and that all household cleaners and toxic substances are locked away in cabinets, with no signs of entry.
Upon arrival to the ED, the patient has a temperature of 38.1°C, a blood pressure of 101/52 mm Hg, a heart rate of 122 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. She appears awake, alert, and nontoxic. On physical examination, she has clear breath sounds bilaterally, no murmurs, a soft nondistended abdomen, lateral nystagmus, and slow comprehension. She falls out of the chair when sitting and looks off balance when walking. She has no rhythmic tonic-clonic activity and no other pertinent examination findings.
A CT scan of the head is normal with no acute bleeding or midline shift. MRI shows multifocal, asymmetric white-matter lesions.
A basic metabolic panel, liver function tests, and complete blood count are within normal limits. Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
Cerebrospinal fluid studies show a negative Gram stain and the following other results:



Patient value
Reference range


Glucose (mg/dL)
65
45–72


Protein (mg/dL)
60
5–45


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
25
<5


Erythrocyte count (per mm3)
0
0


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Friedreich ataxia is a rare, chronic, progressive neurodegenerative disorder that is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This condition usually manifests in childhood as ataxia and is associated with multiple other comorbidities. It does not typically manifest as acutely as this patient’s symptoms have appeared.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has acute ataxia, nystagmus, and slow comprehension in the setting of a viral illness that began several days before presentation. She has a low-grade fever with otherwise normal vital signs. Her neurologic examination and MRI findings raise suspicion for encephalopathy, with acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) as the most likely diagnosis. ADEM is an acute, monophasic demyelinating disorder of the central nervous system (CNS) characterized by neurologic symptoms with evidence of multifocal, asymmetric demyelination of white matter on neuroimaging.

ADEM typically occurs during the winter and spring months and an average of 10 days after a viral infection. Common viruses implicated include influenza, measles, mumps, rubella, varicella, Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus (CMV), and herpes simplex virus (HSV), but the inciting infection is frequently not identified. Patients typically present with nonspecific systemic symptoms including fever, nausea, vomiting, and headache, as well as neurologic signs and symptoms including motor deficits, altered consciousness, sensory deficits, and nystagmus. Ataxia is the most common motor deficit on presentation.

Initial evaluation for ADEM should include laboratory testing, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) studies, and MRI of the brain. Laboratory testing may reveal elevations in the leukocyte count and inflammatory markers, while CSF studies may show normal or elevated protein levels, a normal or elevated leukocyte count, a normal glucose level, and a negative Gram stain and culture. ADEM is managed with intravenous glucocorticoids with or without immunoglobulins. The prognosis is typically good with full recovery.

Key learning point: Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis is associated with multifocal, asymmetric white-matter lesions on MRI.

C) INCORRECT:

Ataxia telangiectasia is a rare, chronic, progressive neurodegenerative disorder that is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This condition usually manifests in childhood as ataxia and is associated with multiple other comorbidities. It does not typically manifest as acutely as this patient’s symptoms have appeared.

D) INCORRECT:

In viral meningitis, the CSF studies typically show a normal or slightly reduced glucose level, a normal or mild increase in protein, an elevated leukocyte count with early neutrophil predominance that then becomes lymphocytic predominance, and a negative Gram stain and positive viral PCR or culture.

Patients with bacterial meningitis are usually irritable, appear ill, and are frequently toxic. CSF studies typically show a low glucose level, high protein level, elevated leukocyte count with neutrophil predominance, and positive Gram stain and bacterial culture.

E) INCORRECT:

Children with acute viral encephalitis typically present with fever, vomiting, altered mental status, and occasional seizures or focal neurologic deficits. Although the infectious causes of acute viral encephalitis (enteroviruses, HSV, CMV, West Nile virus, and influenza) are similar to those of ADEM, the symptoms of acute viral encephalitis are concurrent with the acute infection, rather than developing during the postinfectious stage. As a result, viral cultures and polymerase chain-reaction (PCR) results are more likely to be positive in patients with acute viral encephalitis than in patients with ADEM. CSF findings in acute viral encephalitis are similar to those obtained in viral meningitis, with pleocytosis (initially, neutrophil predominance and then lymphocytic predominance), an elevated protein level, and a normal glucose level. Although MRI findings in patients with acute viral encephalitis can include white-matter lesions, they may also include changes in the temporal lobe, cerebellum, thalami, or basal ganglia, such as hemorrhage, enhancement, and restricted diffusion.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever, confusion, impaired vision, and weakness. Her parents report that her symptoms have worsened rapidly, and she now requires assistance to walk. Two weeks ago, she had an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved spontaneously. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use other substances. Immunizations are up to date. She appears somnolent and is oriented only to person. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. There is minimal movement when a painful stimulus is applied to each limb. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. A CT scan of the head reveals scattered hypodense lesions in the brain parenchyma but is otherwise unremarkable. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows:


Pressure
160 mm H2O


Glucose
60 mg/dL


Total protein
58 mg/dL


Leukocyte count
27/mm3



 Lymphocytes
98%


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis (MS) can manifest with CNS lesions, optic neuritis, and lymphocytic pleocytosis on CSF analysis. However, an MS exacerbation typically develops over days to weeks, unlike the rapidly progressive symptoms seen here, and is not associated with fever, altered mental status, or elevated CSF protein levels.

B) CORRECT:

Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is a multifocal, inflammatory, demyelinating disease of the CNS. This condition predominantly affects children and young adults and occurs days to weeks after a viral infection or vaccination due to cross-reactivity between a viral and myelin antigen. ADEM is characterized by rapid onset and progression of neurological deficits and altered mental status. Patients often have a fever, and CSF analysis typically shows lymphocytic pleocytosis and elevated protein levels. Although the brain is primarily affected, patients can also develop optic neuritis, as seen here, and transverse myelitis. Characteristic neuroimaging findings are multiple poorly defined lesions in deep and subcortical white matter. A CT scan may show parenchymal lesions but is often nondiagnostic, and an MRI is necessary to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment involves high-dose intravenous corticosteroid therapy for 3–5 days.
Image Description:

MRI head (FLAIR; axial plane) of a 60-year-old with rapid cognitive decline starting 2 weeks after an elective dental procedure.

Multiple large confluent hyperintense lesions are demonstrated in both cerebral hemispheres in an asymmetric pattern. The lesions are predominantly located within the white matter (example indicated by green overlay). In addition to these lesions in the supratentorial region, further hyperintense lesions are visible in the midbrain (example indicated by red overlay), indicating infratentorial involvement.

Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is an autoimmune-mediated inflammatory demyelinating condition. It is difficult to differentiate from other inflammatory conditions, especially multiple sclerosis, and tissue diagnosis may be the only way to confirm diagnosis. An immunologic trigger may be present in the clinical history. An infection from the dental procedure in this case may have been the trigger for ADEM.

C) INCORRECT:

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) causes brain lesions and can result in elevated CSF protein levels. However, PML usually affects immunocompromised individuals and progresses over several weeks. Moreover, fever and lymphocytic pleocytosis on CSF analysis do not typically occur in PML.
Image Description:

MRI head (left: T2-weighted; right: diffusion-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with common variable immunodeficiency syndrome

A confluent, hyperintense area (green overlay) without mass effect is seen in the right frontoparietal subcortical white matter. High signal intensity on the diffusion-weighted image (red overlay) indicates diffusion restriction.

The MRI features and immunocompromised state suggest progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), even though PML lesions are typically multifocal, bilateral, and asymmetric. PML lesions generally show little or no mass effect or contrast enhancement.

D) INCORRECT:

Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD) can manifest with rapidly progressive optic neuritis, neurological deficits, and elevated protein and pleocytosis on CSF analysis. However, NMOSD mainly affects the optic nerves and spinal cord. Brainstem and brain involvement are less common in this condition. Additionally, NMOSD typically occurs in adults and is not associated with fever or parainfectious pathogenesis. A recent infection in this patient makes a different condition more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) can occur after a viral infection and manifest with rapidly progressing muscle weakness and elevated protein levels on CSF analysis. However, fever, optic neuritis, brain lesions, and pleocytosis are not typically seen in this condition, and a change in mental status would occur only if the patient develops respiratory failure due to diaphragm paralysis.
questions.hint: Optic disc swelling without elevated intracranial pressure suggests optic neuritis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old white woman comes to the clinic for a follow-up evaluation. She was diagnosed with a neurological disease after experiencing two episodes of numbness, tingling, sensory loss, and weakness in her extremities. Her first episode occurred 2 years ago, and the second one occurred 3 months ago. An MRI performed during the first episode showed contrast-enhancing white matter plaques in the cerebrum. Her symptoms improved substantially 6–8 weeks after the start of each episode, and only mild weakness and sensory deficits persisted between the two episodes. She works as a high school teacher and lives with her partner. Her only medication is interferon beta. She does not smoke, drink alcoholic beverages, or use illicit drugs. The patient appears well and is not in distress. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 65 kg (143 lb); BMI is 23 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Neurological examination reveals 3/5 muscle strength in her right upper extremity and 4/5 in all other extremities. Which of the following factors in this patient’s history most strongly indicates a poor prognosis?

choices.text: Presence of sensory symptoms during the episodes
Incomplete symptom remission in between episodes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Motor and cerebellar symptoms during episodes indicate a poor prognosis. Patients who only have sensory symptoms during an MS exacerbation have a favorable prognosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although MS is most common in White individuals, they typically have a better prognosis than Black and Hispanic individuals with the condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Although MS is more common in female than male individuals, female individuals have a better prognosis.

D) CORRECT:

Relapsing-remitting MS, which is characterized by clearly defined exacerbations with full or incomplete recovery, can progress into secondary progressive MS, in which neurological function continues to worsen. Incomplete symptom remission between episodes indicates a higher risk of progression to secondary progressive MS and a poor prognosis. A single relapse rarely causes permanent disability, but a progressive course indicates accelerated neurodegeneration and increases the risk of permanent disability. Other prognostic factors for disease progression are male sex, age at onset > 40 years, multiple symptoms with early motor and cerebellar involvement, and a high relapse rate in the first 2 years after onset.
Image Description:

Relapsing-remitting (RR) MS (∼ 90 % of patients): either full recovery between exacerbations (left column) or increasing residual disability with each exacerbation (right column).

Secondary progressive (SP) MS: > 50 % of patients initially presenting with relapsing-remitting MS later develop a pattern of continuous progression (left column), which may also include further exacerbations (right column).

Primary progressive(PP) MS (∼ 10 % of patients): continuous worsening of symptoms from disease onset (left column), but may include phases of no progression or even mild clinical improvement (less pronounced than in relapsing-remitting MS; right column). Exacerbations may also occur (not depicted).

E) INCORRECT:

Although the average age of MS onset is 20–40 years, onset at > 40 years of age is associated with a poorer prognosis.
questions.hint: This patient's current clinical presentation and imaging findings during a prior exacerbation are consistent with multiple sclerosis (MS). Relapsing-remitting MS is the most common clinical course, affecting approximately 90% of individuals with MS, including this patient.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the office because of vision impairment in her right eye for the past 2 weeks. She is unable to distinguish colors with her right eye and has pain with eye movement.One year ago, she had a similar episode that resolved spontaneously. Examination shows that the right and left pupils do not constrict when a light is shone into the right eye. Visual acuity is 20/50 in the left eye, and 20/100 in the right eye. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Retinal detachment typically results in sudden, painless, visual field defects or complete loss of vision in the affected eye and is usually preceded by prodromal symptoms such as floaters and/or photopsia. The presence of only defective color vision and moderately decreased visual acuity, as well as the presence of pain, make the diagnosis of retinal detachment extremely unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Retinitis pigmentosa leads to a progressive loss of vision in both eyes and the initial clinical manifestations are night-blindness and decreased peripheral vision. This patient has developed acute visual impairment in one eye and has no difficulty reading in a poorly lit environment.

C) INCORRECT:

Angle-closure glaucoma manifests acutely with eye pain and a decrease in visual acuity. However, other clinical features such as photophobia, nausea, vomiting, corneal cloudiness, congestion of the ciliary and conjunctival vessels, and a fixed, semi-dilated pupil are not seen in this patient. Slit lamp examination in angle-closure glaucoma shows a shallow anterior chamber.

D) INCORRECT:

Common causes of macular degeneration include age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and myopic macular degeneration. AMD usually occurs in people > 60 years old and presents with a slowly progressive, painless, bilateral decrease in visual acuity. Myopic macular degeneration may occur in younger patients and would also present with an insidious, painless loss of vision but is seen in patients with pathological myopia. Patients with pathological myopia would have a deep anterior chamber on slit lamp examination, and an uncorrected visual acuity that is far worse than 20/200 in both eyes.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with optic neuritis, which is often the first manifestation of multiple sclerosis (MS). MS is more common in women than men and it typically manifests at 20–40 years of age, with a relapsing-remitting clinical pattern. Most patients with optic neuritis have a relative afferent pupillary defect and a normal fundus on ophthalmoscopy.

All patients who present with new-onset optic neuritis should undergo a brain MRI to assess for demyelinating plaques, which support a diagnosis of MS.
questions.hint: This 33-year-old female patient presents with acute, unilateral color blindness, a decrease in visual acuity, and pain with eye movements, all of which are consistent with a specific diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of increasing weakness and numbness of the upper extremities for 5 days. During this time, she has also had urinary incontinence unrelated to sneezing or laughing. She reports that last summer during a vacation in Mexico she had weakness and numbness of her right lower extremity that was worse when she was outside. Examination shows an impaired tandem gait and mild spasticity. Muscle strength is decreased in both upper extremities and the right lower extremity. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Sensation to vibration and fine touch is decreased over the upper extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: MRI of the brain and spine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause demyelination of the spinal cord, manifesting as subacute combined degeneration (SACD). SACD could explain many of this patient's symptoms, such as her sensory abnormalities, muscle spasticity and weakness, impaired tandem gait, and urinary incontinence. However, symptoms of SACD are generally symmetrical and involve the legs more than the arms. Furthermore, this patient does not have any other signs of vitamin B12 deficiency, such as fatigue, pallor, or glossitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibodies are used to screen for numerous rheumatic diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or Sjögren syndrome. Neurologic involvement is common in patients with SLE. However, the most common signs of SLE, including skin and joint involvement, are not present. Although SLE may manifest before the onset of other systemic findings, typical findings are cognitive dysfunction, strokes, seizures, and/or headaches, none of which are present in this patient.

Sjögren syndrome can manifest with a variety of focal and/or diffuse neurological abnormalities, e.g., impaired motor control, paresis, seizures, or peripheral neuropathy, making it an important differential diagnosis. But this patient's primary symptoms became worse in the summer heat and demonstrated complete remission, which is not expected with Sjögren syndrome. In addition, most patients with CNS SS also have signs of peripheral vasculitis affecting the skin and muscles such as ulcers or pain. However, in a clinical setting, if the next appropriate step is inconclusive, ANA testing may be considered.

C) CORRECT:

MRI of the brain and spine is the investigation of choice for a definitive diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS). MRI typically shows multiple asymmetric white matter lesions with finger-like radial extensions often located in the spinal cord, juxtacortical, infratentorial, and periventricular regions. If a gadolinium contrast agent is used, active lesions usually appear enhanced up to 6 weeks after exacerbations. This patient most likely has relapsing-remitting MS with symptoms that correspond to lesions in the pyramidal tracts (weakness, spasticity, increased deep tendon reflexes), dorsal spinal column (loss of vibration and fine touch), and autonomic nervous system (urinary incontinence).

Absent abdominal reflex is an early and important sign of MS that is seen in about 70% of patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Electromyography can be helpful in diagnosing amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). While this patient has symptoms of upper motor neuron injury, she does not have other findings seen in patients with ALS, such as lower motor neuron injury (e.g., absent or diminished deep tendon reflexes, flaccid paralysis, atrophy, fasciculations). Moreover, patients with ALS do not experience symptom remission.

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is indicated for cases of suspected multiple sclerosis (MS) in which the first-line diagnostic test is inconclusive. In patients with MS, the cerebral spinal fluid analysis typically shows lymphocytic pleocytosis and oligoclonal bands. While this patient must be assessed for MS, she has not yet received first-line diagnostic testing.
questions.hint: The reversible exacerbation of neurological symptoms following an increase in body temperature (e.g., hot weather, warm bath, physical exertion) is referred to as Uhthoff phenomenon. This phenomenon is characteristic of a certain disease that predominantly affects women of childbearing age.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis presents with leg numbness and weakness that, during the past 2 days, has progressed up both her legs to her lower abdomen. She reports difficulty walking and urinary hesitancy. Physical examination reveals moderate paraparesis, hyperreflexia in the legs, and numbness up to the T12 level. The patient is hospitalized, and MRI shows a gadolinium-enhanced lesion in the upper thoracic spinal cord. Which one of the following acute treatments is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azathioprine is not used to treat MS relapses.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulin is not typically used to manage acute MS exacerbations, although it is used to treat other conditions, including acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (Guillain-Barré syndrome).

C) CORRECT:

Acute inflammatory multiple sclerosis (MS) relapses typically respond to treatment with high-dose glucocorticoids, such as methylprednisolone. No consensus exists about the optimal treatment duration or dose, but a typical regimen is intravenous methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for 3 to 5 days. Oral treatment with high-dose prednisone may also be considered, as several studies have shown noninferiority with these regimens compared to intravenous therapy. Although treatment with high-dose glucocorticoids may shorten the duration of symptoms, studies have not demonstrated any reduction in disability at 6 months.

Key learning point: The most appropriate acute treatment for a disabling multiple sclerosis relapse is a high-dose intravenous glucocorticoid.

D) INCORRECT:

Natalizumab is a chronic disease-modifying medication for MS but is not useful in treating acute relapses.

E) INCORRECT:

Interferon beta-1a is a chronic disease-modifying medication for MS but is not useful in treating acute relapses.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of increasing weakness and numbness of her legs for 3 days. She noticed that the weakness was more severe after she had a hot shower that morning. A year ago, she had an episode of partial vision loss in her left eye that resolved within 3 weeks. She is sexually active with 3 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Examination shows spasticity and decreased muscle strength in the lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response bilaterally. MRI of the brain and spine is inconclusive. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Oligoclonal bands in cerebral spinal fluid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A positive rapid plasma reagin test is a nonspecific laboratory finding that is associated with syphilis, which can manifest with a variety of neurologic symptoms. While this patient is at risk for syphilis given her sexual history (multiple partners with inconsistent barrier use), neurosyphilis is often triggered by immunosuppression (e.g., HIV infection). Moreover, symptoms would be chronic and progressive, whereas this patient's visual symptoms have resolved.

B) INCORRECT:

Peripheral nerve demyelination can be seen in multiple neurological disorders such as Guillain Barré syndrome, which may also cause weakness and sensory changes. However, this patient has evidence of upper motor neuron damage (hyperreflexia, extensor Babinski response), so her disease is localized to the CNS. Moreover, demyelination in patients with MS only occurs within the CNS.

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of fasciculations on electromyography indicates spontaneous nerve activity and is commonly seen in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and other anterior horn degenerative diseases. This patient has MS, which is characterized by slow nerve conduction velocity (seen in up to 70% of cases).
Image Description:

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is a neurodegenerative disease that affects the entire motor neuron system (degeneration of the upper motor neuron in the precentral gyrus and lower motor neuron in the brainstem or anterior horn of the spinal cord). The disease most commonly manifests between 50 and 70 years of age, often beginning with unilateral weakness in the hands or feet, which then progresses to the contralateral side (asymmetric limb weakness). However, initial manifestations are highly variable and individuals may have atypical or nonspecific symptoms such as subtle vocal changes. As the disease progresses, most individuals eventually develop one or both of the life-threatening symptoms: respiratory impairment and dysphagia.

D) INCORRECT:

ELISA is a highly sensitive and specific test to detect HIV infection, which can cause a variety of neurologic symptoms, including weakness, upper motor neuron signs, sensory changes, and visual disturbances. While this patient's sexual history puts her at risk for HIV infection, only patients with HIV-associated dementia would have such extensive HIV destruction of the CNS to cause this constellation of symptoms together. This patient has no evidence of dementia.

E) CORRECT:

The presence of oligoclonal bands in CSF (and their absence in the blood) is highly suggestive of multiple sclerosis (MS). Lumbar puncture is indicated in patients with clinically suspected MS and inconclusive findings on MRI. Other typical findings on CSF examination include lymphocytic pleocytosis and increased myelin basic protein levels. The appearance of oligoclonal bands in the early stages of the disease indicates a poor prognosis.

Key learning point: Oligoclonal bands in cerebrospinal fluid are a characteristic diagnostic finding in multiple sclerosis, reflecting intrathecal IgG synthesis and CNS inflammation.
questions.hint: Relapsing remitting central neurologic symptoms, especially in a woman of childbearing age, are concerning for multiple sclerosis (MS). This patient's visual changes that resolved without treatment likely represent optic neuritis, the most common first manifestation of MS. Hyperreflexia and positive Babinski sign are signs of upper motor neuron dysfunction. Worsening of symptoms following a hot shower is referred to as Uhthoff phenomenon.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents for evaluation of recent-onset monocular vision loss. She reports 4 days of progressive right-sided vision loss that began when she awoke one morning. She noted a large spot in the right hemifield that has continued to enlarge. She has noticed that the color red looks less vivid in her right eye and that she has pain when she moves that eye. One year ago, she experienced 2 weeks of progressive gait imbalance that resolved spontaneously without any residual deficits. Examination of the right eye reveals visual acuity of 20/80, red color desaturation, an enlarged blind spot, and an afferent pupillary defect. The optic disk appears sharp and crisp on fundoscopy. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Occipital lobe stroke would manifest with hemifield vision loss in both eyes, and the affected patient would have a normal pupillary examination. Stroke would also be unlikely in an otherwise healthy 28-year-old woman.

B) INCORRECT:

Ischemic optic neuropathy is caused by ischemia to the optic nerve. Arteritic ischemic optic neuropathy occurs as a complication of arteritis, such as giant-cell arteritis, whereas nonarteritic ischemic optic neuropathy is idiopathic and occurs in the absence of arteritis, most commonly in older patients with vascular risk factors. Nonarteritic anterior ischemic neuropathy (NAION) is the most common form of ischemic optic neuropathy and affects the optic disk, whereas nonarteritic posterior ischemic neuropathy affects the retrobulbar portion of the optic nerve. The classic clinical presentation of NAION is unilateral loss of vision progressing over hours to days. Pain, as was present in this patient, would be very atypical for NAION. In addition, NAION generally manifests with optic nerve swelling (seen as blurring of the optic disk margins) on fundoscopic examination, which was absent in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with unilateral optic neuritis, a common condition found in people with multiple sclerosis (MS). Although visual field loss is the cardinal symptom of optic neuritis, pain with eye movement is another common symptom. Other typical presentations of MS include focal supratentorial syndrome, focal brainstem or cerebellar syndrome, and partial myelopathy.

Historically, MS has been diagnosed on the basis of patient-reported symptoms as well as objective clinical findings that reflect focal or multifocal inflammatory demyelinating events in the central nervous system (CNS). Diagnosis required that the patient have at least two discrete clinical events that were disseminated in time (lasting at least 24 hours each and separated by a period of at least 30 days) and also disseminated in space (with symptoms originating from at least two different CNS sites). This patient would have met the diagnostic criteria, as her prior episode of ataxia suggests a lesion in the brain or spinal cord separated in time and space from the current presentation of optic neuritis.

More recently, the diagnostic criteria for MS have been updated, and the requirement for two different neurologic events separated by 30 days has been eliminated. A diagnosis of MS can now be made in patients who have only one clinical event if they also have either (a) MRI findings demonstrating dissemination in space or (b) cerebrospinal fluid analysis demonstrating the presence of oligoclonal bands unique to the CNS.

Key learning point: The classic diagnosis of multiple sclerosis requires symptoms occurring in different parts of the central nervous system and as discrete episodes separated by at least 30 days.

D) INCORRECT:

Migraine with aura can cause some of the findings noted on this patient’s examination, but aura typically lasts no more than 60 minutes, often with coincident migraine headache. In addition, the age of onset for migraine is usually earlier than age 28, and this patient has no prior history of headaches noted.

E) INCORRECT:

Leber hereditary optic neuropathy, which is caused by an uncommon mitochondrial DNA mutation, is associated with optic neuritis that can start anywhere between 1 and 60 years of age. It can be associated with symptoms similar to those of multiple sclerosis and is diagnosed by testing for DNA point mutations. Given that approximately 90% of cases occur in males, this condition would be much less likely than multiple sclerosis in this patient.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with intermittent episodes of tingling and numbness in both lower extremities, each lasting several days before partially resolving. She also reports a recent episode of blurred vision in her left eye that improved spontaneously. Neurological examination shows mild spasticity in both legs and decreased sensation below the knees. Routine blood tests, including complete blood count and inflammatory markers, are normal. She denies any joint pain or swelling, and rheumatoid factor testing has not been performed (see report).
MRI of the brain: Multiple scattered hyperintense lesions in the periventricular white matter
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis is an immune-mediated demyelinating disease that predominantly affects young adults, especially women. The patient's recurrent episodes of sensory disturbances and transient blurred vision suggest dissemination in time, a hallmark of multiple sclerosis. The MRI findings of multiple hyperintense lesions in the periventricular white matter indicate dissemination in space, characteristic of demyelinating plaques. These clinical and imaging findings reflect the autoimmune attack on myelin, leading to episodic central nervous system dysfunction and variable neurologic deficits.

Key learning point: Multiple sclerosis is characterized by demyelinating lesions in the CNS, often seen on MRI as hyperintense lesions in the periventricular white matter. In rheumatoid arthritis, if disease activity is not controlled with methotrexate, a biologic agent is often added to the treatment regimen.

B) INCORRECT:

Neuromyelitis optica primarily affects the optic nerves and spinal cord, often causing severe, bilateral optic neuritis and longitudinally extensive spinal cord lesions. The patient's single episode of blurred vision and MRI findings of periventricular lesions are more indicative of multiple sclerosis. Neuromyelitis optica typically presents with different lesion distribution and more severe optic nerve involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with central nervous system involvement often presents with diffuse symptoms like seizures or cognitive dysfunction, not discrete relapsing episodes. The patient lacks systemic features of SLE, such as rash or arthritis. MRI findings of periventricular lesions are more typical of demyelinating diseases than the vascular lesions seen in SLE-related CNS vasculopathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) usually follows an infection or vaccination and presents as a monophasic event with encephalopathy. The patient's recurrent episodes and lack of preceding infection or systemic illness are inconsistent with ADEM. Additionally, ADEM typically shows large, confluent lesions on MRI, unlike the scattered periventricular lesions observed here.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with 3 days of progressive numbness and weakness in her right leg. She has a 5-year history of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis and is not on any disease-modifying therapy. She denies recent illness. Vital signs are stable. She is alert with no signs of infection. Neurological examination shows spastic tone and decreased vibratory sensation in the right lower extremity. Serum studies, including a complete blood count and electrolytes, are normal (see report).
MRI of the spine with gadolinium: Enhancing lesion at T10 consistent with active demyelination
Which of the following interventions is most appropriate to manage her acute symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous interferon beta is a disease-modifying therapy used to reduce future relapses in relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis. It does not provide the immediate anti-inflammatory effects needed for acute exacerbations, which require rapid intervention with high-dose corticosteroids.

B) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis is reserved for multiple sclerosis relapses that do not respond to high-dose corticosteroids. It is not the initial treatment for acute exacerbations, especially when there is no indication of corticosteroid treatment failure or contraindication.

C) CORRECT:

Acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis are characterized by active inflammatory demyelination in the central nervous system. High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone is the preferred treatment as it rapidly reduces inflammation by modulating the immune response and decreasing pro-inflammatory cytokines. This intervention helps restore the blood-brain barrier's integrity, shortens the relapse duration, and improves neurological function. The presence of an enhancing lesion on MRI with gadolinium supports the need for this treatment, which is typically administered over several days to alleviate acute symptoms in relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis.

Key learning point: Acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis are best treated with high-dose intravenous corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and hasten recovery.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is not well-supported for acute multiple sclerosis exacerbations. It is considered when corticosteroids are contraindicated or ineffective, neither of which applies to this patient. High-dose corticosteroids remain the standard treatment for acute relapses.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to your clinic with vision impairment in her right eye for the past 2 weeks. She reports difficulty distinguishing colors with her right eye and experiences pain with eye movement. She had a similar episode one year ago that resolved on its own. On examination, neither pupil constricts when light is directed into the right eye. Visual acuity is 20/50 in the left eye and 20/100 in the right eye. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Retinal detachment typically results in sudden, painless, visual field defects or complete loss of vision in the affected eye and is usually preceded by prodromal symptoms such as floaters and/or photopsia. The presence of only defective color vision and moderately decreased visual acuity, as well as the presence of pain, make the diagnosis of retinal detachment extremely unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Angle-closure glaucoma manifests acutely with eye pain and a decrease in visual acuity. However, other clinical features such as photophobia, nausea, vomiting, corneal cloudiness, congestion of the ciliary and conjunctival vessels, and a fixed, semi-dilated pupil are not seen in this patient. Slit lamp examination in angle-closure glaucoma shows a shallow anterior chamber.

C) INCORRECT:

Common causes of macular degeneration include age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and myopic macular degeneration. AMD usually occurs in people > 60 years old and presents with a slowly progressive, painless, bilateral decrease in visual acuity. Myopic macular degeneration may occur in younger patients and would also present with an insidious, painless loss of vision but is seen in patients with pathological myopia. Patients with pathological myopia would have a deep anterior chamber on slit lamp examination, and an uncorrected visual acuity that is far worse than 20/200 in both eyes.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with optic neuritis, which is often the first manifestation of multiple sclerosis (MS). MS is more common in women than men and it typically manifests at 20–40 years of age, with a relapsing-remitting clinical pattern. Most patients with optic neuritis have a relative afferent pupillary defect and a normal fundus on ophthalmoscopy.

All patients who present with new-onset optic neuritis should undergo a brain MRI to assess for demyelinating plaques, which support a diagnosis of MS.

Key learning point: Optic neuritis typically presents in young adults with unilateral vision loss, pain with eye movement, and impaired color vision, and is often associated with multiple sclerosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Retinitis pigmentosa leads to a progressive loss of vision in both eyes and the initial clinical manifestations are night-blindness and decreased peripheral vision. This patient has developed acute visual impairment in one eye and has no difficulty reading in a poorly lit environment.
questions.hint: This 33-year-old female patient presents with acute, unilateral color blindness, a decrease in visual acuity, and pain with eye movements, all of which are consistent with a specific diagnosis.

questions.text: You are caring for a 48-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis who presents with 2 days of progressive leg numbness and weakness that has ascended to her lower abdomen. She reports difficulty walking and urinary hesitancy. On examination, she has moderate paraparesis, hyperreflexia in the legs, and sensory loss up to the T12 level. She is admitted to hospital. MRI of the spine shows a gadolinium-enhanced lesion in the upper thoracic spinal cord. Which one of the following acute treatments is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azathioprine is not used to treat MS relapses.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulin is not typically used to manage acute MS exacerbations, although it is used to treat other conditions, including acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy (Guillain-Barré syndrome).

C) INCORRECT:

Interferon beta-1a is a chronic disease-modifying medication for MS but is not useful in treating acute relapses.

D) CORRECT:

Acute inflammatory multiple sclerosis (MS) relapses typically respond to treatment with high-dose glucocorticoids, such as methylprednisolone. No consensus exists about the optimal treatment duration or dose, but a typical regimen is intravenous methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for 3 to 5 days. Oral treatment with high-dose prednisone may also be considered, as several studies have shown noninferiority with these regimens compared to intravenous therapy. Although treatment with high-dose glucocorticoids may shorten the duration of symptoms, studies have not demonstrated any reduction in disability at 6 months.

Key learning point: The most appropriate acute treatment for a disabling multiple sclerosis relapse is a high-dose intravenous glucocorticoid.

E) INCORRECT:

Natalizumab is a chronic disease-modifying medication for MS but is not useful in treating acute relapses.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to your clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. She reports feeling well. She was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis 1 year ago and has had two exacerbations since then, each lasting 1 week and requiring hospitalization for corticosteroid treatment. Her most recent exacerbation was 3 weeks ago. She has not experienced neurological symptoms between exacerbations. She does not smoke and drinks one glass of wine per week. Her daily medications include a multivitamin and a calcium supplement. Vital signs are normal. Examination, including neurological assessment, is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Supportive therapy is indicated for symptomatic relief in patients with spasticity (e.g., baclofen, physiotherapy), painful paresthesias (e.g., carbamazepine, amitriptyline), urinary retention (e.g., intermittent catheterization), and/or urinary incontinence (e.g., oxybutynin). This patient is in remission; rather than give supportive therapy only as needed, a disease-modifying drug should be initiated to decrease the occurrence of exacerbations.

B) CORRECT:

Monoclonal antibodies (e.g., natalizumab, ocrelizumab) have the highest efficacy for reducing exacerbations of MS. Natalizumab can be used in most forms of MS to prevent relapses. It binds to integrin receptors on endothelial cells, which prevents integrins from binding to these receptors (and consequently trigger leukocyte chemotaxis to the site of inflammation). In patients with MS, natalizumab binds the alpha-4-integrin receptors and inhibits lymphocyte invasion of the central nervous system. Natalizumab has been associated with an increased risk of developing progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy and patients should, therefore, be carefully monitored.

Other medications that can be used as first-line disease-modifying drugs in relapsing-remitting MS include interferon beta, glatiramer acetate, dimethyl fumarate, teriflunomide, and fingolimod. The adverse effects profile should be taken into consideration when selecting medications for patients: lower efficacy medications (e.g., interferon beta, glatiramer acetate) often have fewer side effects than monoclonal antibodies.

Key learning point: Disease-modifying therapies such as monoclonal antibodies (e.g., natalizumab) are indicated for long-term prevention of relapses in relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Mitoxantrone is used as a second-line or third-line disease-modifying drug for relapsing-remitting MS when the number of exacerbations is not controlled by first-line drugs. Mitoxantrone is not used as a first-line drug because of its association with cardiotoxicity and immunosuppression.

D) INCORRECT:

Interferon beta (IFN beta) rather than interferon alpha (IFN alpha) is used in the management of MS. IFN beta can be used in the long-term management of most forms of MS to prevent relapses. It prevents exacerbations of MS by downregulating the expression of major histocompatibility complex molecules on antigen-presenting cells, inhibiting T-cell proliferation, and decreasing the level of proinflammatory cytokines while increasing the level of regulatory cytokines. IFN alpha is used to treat chronic hepatitis B and C, and can also be used off-label for myeloproliferative disorders, but not MS.

E) INCORRECT:

Methylprednisolone is used to treat acute relapses of MS, but it is not effective at preventing relapses.
questions.hint: This patient has relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (MS) based on multiple episodes of neurological symptoms with a complete return to baseline in between. This asymptomatic period is an ideal time to start her on a first-line agent for long-term treatment of her condition.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of vision loss in her left eye and pain that worsens with eye movement. She reports difficulty distinguishing colors and describes her vision as "looking through frosted glass." Visual acuity is 20/200 in the affected eye with normal fundoscopic findings. On swinging-flashlight test, when light is shone on the unaffected right eye, both pupils constrict normally, but when the light is rapidly transferred to the affected left eye, both pupils dilate. She denies headache, nausea, or systemic symptoms. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: MRI head and orbits with and without IV contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although indirect fundoscopy can provide additional examination details, it is not the most appropriate next step; fundoscopy may be normal in retrobulbar neuritis, which involves inflammation of the retrobulbar part of the optic nerve. As this patient's clinical presentation already strongly suggests optic neuritis, the priority is neuroimaging to evaluate for demyelinating lesions and establish the underlying etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture for CSF analysis is commonly performed to support a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS) and exclude other inflammatory conditions, but it is not a first-line diagnostic test for suspected optic neuritis. The finding of oligoclonal bands in CSF but not in blood supports a diagnosis of MS, but CSF is typically obtained after initial neuroimaging has been performed to identify demyelinating lesions.

C) INCORRECT:

High-dose corticosteroids such as IV methylprednisolone are used for the treatment of acute optic neuritis and may improve recovery time. However, treatment should not be initiated until a diagnostic workup has been completed to evaluate for underlying multiple sclerosis or other causes.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – MRI head and orbits with and without IV contrast is the first-line imaging study for suspected optic neuritis. This patient presents with classic findings, including subacute monocular vision loss, orbital pain with eye movement, dyschromatopsia, and a positive swinging-flashlight test indicating a relative afferent pupillary defect. MRI can identify demyelinating lesions as well as help to establish whether they represent an isolated episode or are due to multiple sclerosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Temporal artery biopsy is indicated for suspected giant cell arteritis, which typically affects older patients and manifests with systemic symptoms, including headache, jaw claudication, and constitutional symptoms. This patient's clinical presentation and age are not consistent with giant cell arteritis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of numbness and weakness in her right leg and numbness in her left foot. She reports that when she flexes her neck forward, she experiences a brief electric shock-like sensation that travels down her spine. Physical examination shows decreased vibration and position sensation in both feet, weakness and hyperreflexia in the right leg, and a positive Babinski sign on the right. She mentions that six months ago she had several weeks of double vision that resolved spontaneously. Brain MRI shows multiple demyelinated plaques in the periventricular white matter with finger-like radial extensions, none of which enhance with gadolinium. Spinal cord MRI shows demyelinated plaques at C4 and T8 levels, with the T8 lesion showing gadolinium enhancement. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause sensory neuropathy and dorsal column dysfunction, but it does not typically cause the Lhermitte sign, asymmetric motor weakness with hyperreflexia, positive Babinski sign, or brain and spinal cord MRI findings of demyelinated plaques, which are characteristic of a different condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome typically manifests with ascending weakness and areflexia, not asymmetric weakness with hyperreflexia and positive Babinski sign. The chronic relapsing-remitting pattern and brain and spinal cord MRI findings of demyelinated plaques are not consistent with this acute inflammatory polyneuropathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Neuromyelitis optica typically manifests with more severe spinal cord involvement (complete transverse myelitis) than what is seen in this patient, severe optic neuritis, and brainstem and diencephalic lesions. Periventricular demyelinated plaques with Dawson fingers are characteristic of a different condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis typically occurs after an infection or vaccination and manifests as a monophasic illness. The relapsing-remitting pattern with a previous episode six months ago and the mixed enhancement pattern of demyelinated plaques that suggest lesions of different ages are consistent with a different condition.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient meets the McDonald Criteria for multiple sclerosis, which requires both dissemination in space (DIS) and dissemination in time (DIT). DIS is evidenced by demyelinated plaques in different CNS regions (periventricular brain, cervical and thoracic spinal cord). The mixed enhancement pattern (T8 spinal cord plaque enhances with gadolinium, indicating active demyelination, while brain and C4 plaques do not enhance, suggesting older demyelinated lesions) and clinical history of a previous episode are evidence of DIT. This patient's presentation is consistent with partial transverse myelitis, a common early manifestation of multiple sclerosis, which is likely causing the asymmetrical neurological dysfunction below the T8 level lesion, while the cervical lesion is causing the characteristic Lhermitte sign.

questions.text: A 28-year-old previously healthy woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of progressive left leg weakness and numbness. She also reports burning sensations in her right leg and says that it "feels different." She denies recent trauma. Physical examination shows left lower extremity weakness (4/5 strength); intact right leg strength (5/5); loss of proprioception, vibration, and fine touch discrimination in the left leg; loss of pain and temperature sensation in the right leg; and hyperreflexia in the left leg. What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation?

choices.text: CT of the thoracic and lumbar spine
MRI of the brain and spine with and without gadolinium
Lumbar puncture with CSF analysis for oligoclonal bands

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ipsilateral motor weakness and loss of dorsal column sensation with contralateral loss of spinothalamic sensation and no recent trauma suggests Brown-Séquard syndrome due to a medical cause. CT does not adequately evaluate for demyelinating lesions or other spinal cord pathology.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – Ipsilateral motor weakness and loss of dorsal column sensation (proprioception, vibration, and fine touch discrimination) with contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation is consistent with Brown-Séquard syndrome due to hemisection of the spinal cord. In a previously healthy young patient with no history of trauma, this pattern suggests partial transverse myelitis as a common early manifestation of multiple sclerosis. MRI of the brain and spine with and without gadolinium is the imaging study of choice to evaluate demyelinating lesions and assess dissemination in both time and space. Gadolinium enhancement helps identify active lesions.

C) INCORRECT:

CSF analysis for oligoclonal bands is a valuable part of the evaluation of suspected multiple sclerosis, but the first step is to confirm the clinical suspicion of demyelinating disease and evaluate the extent of CNS involvement with appropriate imaging studies.

D) INCORRECT:

Asymmetrical partial transverse myelitis is more consistent with multiple sclerosis than neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorders (NMOSD), which typically manifest with symmetrical complete transverse myelitis and severe optic neuritis. Even if NMOSD is suspected, radiological assessment to confirm demyelinating disease and evaluate the extent and pattern of CNS involvement should precede serological testing.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause subacute combined degeneration with posterior and lateral spinal column involvement, but it typically manifests with a more gradual onset over months and bilateral symmetrical symptoms, unlike this patient's presentation of acute asymmetrical Brown-Séquard syndrome.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a known history of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis treated with glatiramer acetate presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of new progressive diplopia and right-sided facial weakness. Vital signs are BP, 126/78; P, 88; R, 16; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F). Oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Neurologic examination shows right lower facial weakness with preserved forehead wrinkling and eye closure. On extraocular movement testing, she has impaired adduction of the right eye with nystagmus in the left eye on rightward gaze, but convergence remains intact. The remainder of her neurologic examination is unchanged from baseline. MRI brain shows new T2-hyperintense lesions in the brainstem with gadolinium enhancement, along with multiple non-enhancing T2-hyperintense lesions in the periventricular and subcortical white matter. What is the most appropriate intervention for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with an acute multiple sclerosis (MS) exacerbation with new function-limiting cranial nerve deficits including central facial palsy and diplopia from internuclear ophthalmoplegia. The gadolinium-enhancing brainstem lesions suggest acute demyelination. High-dose glucocorticoid pulse therapy is the first-line therapy for acute MS exacerbations that affect physical functioning.

B) INCORRECT:

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) gel is an alternative therapy for multiple sclerosis (MS) exacerbations. Evidence for alternative therapies is not as strong as that for first-line therapy, and their use is not well-defined.

C) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis is not a first-line therapy for multiple sclerosis (MS) exacerbations. It is typically reserved for patients who have a poor response to first-line therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Switching disease-modifying therapy addresses long-term management to prevent future exacerbations but does not treat the current acute exacerbation. This patient's new neurologic deficits require immediate intervention with acute therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Clinical monitoring alone is inappropriate for this patient who has new function-limiting neurologic deficits. Acute multiple sclerosis (MS) exacerbations that affect physical functioning require treatment to reduce inflammation and potentially improve recovery.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a known history of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of fever, myalgias, runny nose, sore throat, and nonproductive cough. Vital signs are BP, 118/76; P, 102; R, 18; T, 38.8°C (101.8°F); and oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. She reports significant worsening of her baseline left leg weakness and numbness over the past 2 days. Her last known MS exacerbation was 8 months ago. Physical examination shows clear nasal discharge, erythematous throat, and clear lung sounds bilaterally. Neurological examination shows 4/5 strength in the left lower extremity (baseline 4+/5), decreased sensation to light touch over the left leg, hyperreflexia in bilateral lower extremities, but no neck stiffness. MRI of the brain and spine shows multiple nonenhancing demyelinating lesions in the periventricular white matter and thoracic spinal cord, similar to her most recent imaging from 3 months ago. Which of the following interventions is most likely to improve this patient's worsened neurological symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's MRI shows nonenhancing lesions similar to previous imaging. The absence of gadolinium enhancement and new lesions suggests this is not a true multiple sclerosis (MS) exacerbation, but rather Uhthoff phenomenon, a reversible exacerbation of neurological symptoms in patients with MS caused by increased body temperature. The mechanism involves temperature-dependent impairment of impulse conduction in demyelinated nerves. Treatment focuses on reducing body temperature through antipyretics and cooling measures, which should lead to improvement of the neurological symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose IV methylprednisolone is used for acute multiple sclerosis exacerbations caused by new demyelinating lesions. However, this patient's MRI shows nonenhancing lesions similar to previous imaging. The absence of gadolinium enhancement and new lesions suggests this is not a true exacerbation but rather Uhthoff phenomenon, which does not require immunosuppressive treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Baclofen is used to treat spasticity in patients with multiple sclerosis but would not address the underlying cause of this patient's worsened neurological symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis is an alternative treatment for true multiple sclerosis exacerbations when corticosteroids are contraindicated or ineffective. However, the MRI findings show no gadolinium enhancement or new lesions, indicating this patient's worsening neurological symptoms are not caused by a true multiple sclerosis exacerbation.

E) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics are indicated for bacterial infections but not for the upper respiratory symptoms described. This patient's presentation suggests a viral illness, and antibiotics would not address the underlying cause of her worsened neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis presents with a 3-day history of urinary frequency and urgency, now with difficulty initiating urination. She reports occasional mild urinary hesitancy over the past several months that has progressively worsened. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows a palpable bladder and bilateral lower extremity hyperreflexia. Urinalysis shows no leukocytes, nitrites, or bacteria. Post-void residual is 400 mL. MRI brain and spine shows multiple nonenhancing periventricular white matter lesions and thoracic spinal cord demyelinating plaques consistent with her known disease, unchanged from prior imaging. After successful urethral catheterization with drainage of 450 mL of clear urine, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis.
Arrange intermittent catheterization training and discharge with neurology follow-up.
Discharge with an indwelling transurethral catheter and urology follow-up.
Discharge with a trial of oxybutynin and same week neurology follow.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Imaging of the abdomen and pelvis is not indicated because structural bladder outlet obstruction is unlikely in a young woman with known spinal cord demyelinating lesions. The successful catheterization, absence of systemic symptoms, and normal urinalysis support neurogenic bladder rather than anatomical obstruction requiring imaging evaluation.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- The significant post-void residual volume and clinical presentation indicate neurogenic bladder with urinary retention from detrusor underactivity or detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia. This represents chronic progressive dysfunction rather than an acute exacerbation, as evidenced by the gradual worsening over months and unchanged MRI findings. Intermittent catheterization is the preferred long-term management for neurogenic bladder dysfunction in multiple sclerosis patients. Neurology follow-up ensures appropriate disease monitoring and optimization of therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Indwelling catheters increase infection risk and are not appropriate for long-term management of neurogenic bladder. Clean intermittent catheterization is the preferred approach for chronic urinary retention in multiple sclerosis patients with preserved cognitive function. Urology follow-up is not the immediate priority because this represents neurogenic bladder from known multiple sclerosis rather than a primary urological condition.

D) INCORRECT:

The MRI shows no gadolinium enhancement or new lesions, indicating this represents chronic neurogenic bladder dysfunction rather than an acute multiple sclerosis exacerbation requiring immunosuppressive therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Anticholinergic medications like oxybutynin are used for urinary frequency and overactive bladder symptoms, but this patient has urinary retention requiring mechanical drainage rather than bladder relaxation therapy. Oxybutynin may worsen urinary retention by further decreasing detrusor contractility.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis presents with a 3-day history of progressive leg weakness and difficulty walking. She has a history of occasional visual disturbances and fatigue but states these current symptoms are different from her usual relapses. Physical examination shows asymmetric weakness in both legs (left 3/5, right 4/5), hyperreflexia, and reduced sensation below the umbilicus. She reports new difficulty with bladder control. What is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: MRI of the spine with and without contrast
Lumbar puncture with cerebrospinal fluid analysis
MRI of the brain with and without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While high-dose corticosteroids are the standard treatment for multiple sclerosis exacerbations, urgent imaging must be obtained first to evaluate for transverse myelitis and exclude spinal cord compression.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Progressive bilateral weakness with reduced sensation below the umbilicus and new bladder dysfunction in a patient with multiple sclerosis suggest transverse myelitis. Transverse myelitis can manifest with asymmetric paraplegia with sensory loss and bladder dysfunction and is a common early feature of multiple sclerosis. The combination of bilateral weakness, sensory level, and sphincter dysfunction requires urgent spinal imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Cerebrospinal fluid analysis is not the initial priority in this patient with acute bilateral weakness and sphincter dysfunction. These findings suggest structural spinal cord pathology, which requires urgent imaging evaluation rather than cerebrospinal fluid examination.

D) INCORRECT:

The acute bilateral weakness with a sensory level and new bladder dysfunction cannot wait for routine neurology consultation. This patient requires immediate imaging to assess for spinal cord pathology that could result in permanent neurological damage.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI brain with and without gadolinium is indicated for all patients with suspected multiple sclerosis to assess for characteristic periventricular white matter lesions and support the diagnosis. However, this patient has a known diagnosis of multiple sclerosis and her presentation with bilateral weakness and a reduced sensation below the level of the umbilicus suggests spinal cord pathology rather than new brain lesions.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of blurry vision in his right eye and pain with eye movement for the past three days. Over the past year, he has had intermittent numbness and tingling in his left arm, exacerbated by physical exertion. He was born and raised in Minnesota and has lived there for his entire life. He works as an accountant and spends most of his time indoors. He follows a vegan diet and does not take any supplements. He drinks one glass of wine daily. Family history is remarkable for Hashimoto thyroiditis in his mother. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows decreased visual acuity in the right eye and a relative afferent pupillary defect. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing risk factor for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Maternal history of autoimmune thyroid disease

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Female sex is a risk factor for developing MS, and the condition is more common in women than in men.

B) INCORRECT:

A maternal history of autoimmune disease increases the general risk for autoimmune conditions due to shared genetic and environmental factors. While Hashimoto thyroiditis is associated with other autoimmune diseases (e.g., type 1 diabetes, SLE, Graves disease, Addison disease) and non-Hodgkin lymphoma, it is not associated with an increased risk of developing MS.

C) CORRECT:

Low vitamin D levels are a significant risk factor for developing multiple sclerosis, especially in individuals living at higher latitudes with limited sunlight exposure and insufficient dietary intake. This patient’s lifelong residence in Minnesota (north of the equator), vegan diet without supplementation, and mostly indoor lifestyle all contribute to low vitamin D levels. Other environmental risk factors that play a role in developing MS include cigarette smoking, certain infections (e.g., EBV, HHV-6), and obesity in early life. Early recognition of vitamin D deficiency as a modifiable MS risk factor is clinically important, and supplementation must be considered in at-risk populations.

D) INCORRECT:

A sedentary lifestyle is associated with certain diseases, including cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, and metabolic syndrome. However, sedentary lifestyle is not a risk factor for developing MS.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic excessive alcohol use can cause neurological symptoms (e.g., ataxia, confusion, nystagmus) due to thiamine deficiency. However, this patient’s reported intake of one glass of wine per day does not meet the criteria for chronic heavy alcohol use. His symptoms and clinical findings are more consistent with demyelinating disease than alcohol-related neurotoxicity. Alcohol is not a primary risk factor for developing MS.
questions.hint: This patient presents with acute, painful monocular vision loss and a relative afferent pupillary defect, which is consistent with optic neuritis. He has a history of intermittent sensory symptoms that are exacerbated by exertion, and he has always lived north of the equator, which supports a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of progressive numbness and tingling in both legs. She reports a similar, but milder, episode 6 months ago that resolved spontaneously. She also recalls an episode of painful, blurry vision in her right eye last year that improved over several weeks. On examination, there is decreased sensation to light touch in the lower extremities and hyperreflexia in the patellar and Achilles tendons. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present on physical examination?

choices.text: Cogwheel rigidity on passive range of motion
Worsening diplopia with sustained upward gaze
Afferent pupillary defect in the right eye

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cogwheel rigidity is a form of increased muscle tone characterized by a ratchet-like, intermittent resistance to passive movement. It is a classic finding in Parkinson disease, which results from pathology in the basal ganglia. While patients with multiple sclerosis can develop spasticity, cogwheel rigidity is not a typical feature.

B) INCORRECT:

A stocking-glove pattern describes sensory loss that is most prominent in the distal extremities and gradually lessens proximally. This is the hallmark of a length-dependent peripheral polyneuropathy, commonly caused by diabetes mellitus. The sensory deficits in multiple sclerosis are due to CNS lesions and typically follow non-length-dependent or dermatomal patterns.

C) INCORRECT:

Fatigability, or worsening muscle weakness with repetitive use, is the pathognomonic feature of myasthenia gravis, a disorder of the neuromuscular junction. While diplopia can occur in multiple sclerosis (e.g., from an internuclear ophthalmoplegia), the specific finding of worsening symptoms with sustained gaze suggests myasthenia gravis.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's history of painful, blurry vision in one eye is classic for optic neuritis, a common initial presentation of multiple sclerosis (MS). Even after visual acuity improves, a residual afferent pupillary defect (APD), or Marcus Gunn pupil, often persists. An APD is a sign of optic nerve dysfunction in which the affected pupil paradoxically dilates when a light is swung from the normal eye to it. This patient's presentation of lower extremity paresthesias with hyperreflexia (an upper motor neuron sign) represents a second distinct neurological event, fulfilling the criteria for MS of dissemination in time and space.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of neurological symptoms that are separated in time (multiple episodes) and anatomical space (optic nerve, spinal cord) is characteristic of multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of numbness, fatigue, and blurry vision for 1 week. The symptoms are worse after a hot shower or bath. She had an episode of right arm weakness 2 years ago that resolved without intervention. She recently returned from a hiking trip in upstate New York. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F) and blood pressure is 100/66 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to light touch in the left hand, right thigh, and right flank. Strength is normal. There is left-sided photophobia and pupillary constriction in the left eye is decreased compared to the right eye. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of the disease process in this patient?

choices.text: Spirochete protein cross-reactivity in the meninges
Antibody binding at the neuromuscular junction
Immune complex deposition in the arterial endothelium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spirochete protein cross-reactivity in the meninges is characteristic of aseptic meningitis caused by late-stage Lyme disease (neuroborreliosis). This patient has no history of tick bite or erythema migrans to suggest Lyme disease infection. Symptoms of meningitis include headache, neck stiffness, fevers, and altered mental status, none of which are present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Osmotically-mediated Schwann cell damage is observed in diabetic neuropathy due to chronic hyperglycemia. Diabetic neuropathy has a stocking-glove distribution and is associated with dysesthesias and loss of sensation. This patient lacks a history of diabetes mellitus and her sensory changes have a different distribution.

C) CORRECT:

Multiple sclerosis is an immune-mediated demyelinating disease that is most commonly diagnosed in women aged 20–40 years. Although the pathophysiology is not fully understood, it is believed that Th1 cells react to myelin basic proteins and initiate an inflammatory response, leading to focal demyelination of white matter in the brain and spinal cord. Typical clinical features include transient, isolated episodes of optic neuritis, diplopia, limb weakness, sensory deficits, and ataxia that fully or partially resolve in days to weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

The pathophysiology of myasthenia gravis involves binding of acetylcholine receptor antibodies to the postsynaptic neuron, resulting in impaired neuromuscular transmission. Symptoms of MG typically begin with vision changes due to ocular muscle weakness before progressing to generalized muscle weakness. Although this patient has visual changes and fatigue, the isolated nature of her right arm weakness is not characteristic of MG. Furthermore, MG symptoms are exacerbated by physical activity and improve with rest and do not typically change in response to warm temperatures.

E) INCORRECT:

Vasculitis due to deposition of immune complexes in the arterial endothelium can be seen in systemic lupus erythematosus and Henoch-Schönlein purpura. Vasculitides may cause neurological involvement, such as mononeuritis multiplex, which typically presents with painful sensory and/or motor deficits. This patient lacks classic findings of vasculitis, including palpable purpura, renal involvement (glomerulonephritis), and arthralgias.

F) INCORRECT:

Lymphocytic infiltrate of the endoneurium leading to myelin damage is seen in Guillain-Barré syndrome. This syndrome causes polyneuropathy and ascending flaccid paralysis and typically follows a viral or bacterial gastrointestinal infection (most commonly Campylobacter jejuni). This patient has no history of recent infection and lacks the characteristic features of GBS.
questions.hint: This patient presents with characteristic findings of multiple sclerosis including optic neuritis (impaired vision), Uhthoff phenomenon (worsening of symptoms in response to increased body temperature), as well as episodes of sensory and motor deficits followed by periods of remission.
